Eliminate unused code, field in HBaseStatus

This commit deletes some unused code from some of the utility classes
that start and stop HBase daemons during testing.

Adding ES daemon helper to support Faunus tests

The vast majority of ES-backed tests work fine with local-mode where
ES runs embedded and does not accept sockets.  However, this does not
work well with Faunus.  Running many short-lived map or reduce tasks,
each with its own embedded ES instance running in local-mode tends to
cause a wave of unclean ES shutdowns.  Starting a backgrounded ES
daemon in an external process and then running Faunus + Titan + ES
tests against that external process is cleaner.

This commit introduces a Java utility class that starts and stops an
external ES daemon to support Faunus tests.  The daemon writes a
pidfile /tmp/titan-test-es.pid and writes data to
titan-es/target/es-data.  The config and scripts are lifted from the
ES 1.2.1 distribution.  Some of the pom glue and utility class code
are adapted from similar previous work in titan-hbase.

The recently introduced CassandraESReindexTest class already requires
an external ES daemon to succeed.  This commit just adds automated
tooling to provide one and adds a @BeforeClass to
CassandraESReindexTest that uses it.

titan-dist pom optimization

Tweaking Maven plugin execution bindings to skip pointless plugin runs
and slightly shorten execution times.

Tweak lib file filter for zip/tar archives

The zipfile/tarfile assembly descriptor is now slightly more
inclusive.  It used to exclude any jar in the dependency tree with
classifier tests, javadoc, shared-resources, or example-data.  Of
those, tests could have potentially been problematic; there are some
dependencies in the titan-dist tree that in turn depend on artifacts
with classifier "tests" yet have dependency scope "compile".  Anything
with compile scope should go into lib, and now that's the case, even
if the classifier is "tests".  It's possible that these compile scopes
are just oversights in the poms of our dependencies, but I can't
easily tell and it's not worth the risk of excluding them.

Fix Hadoop bytecode incompatibility leaks

This commit fixes several more instances of Job.getConfiguration() and
TaskAttemptContext.getConfiguration() lingering in titan-hadoop-core.
These calls can't be made directly from titan-hadoop-core because the
Job and TAC types changed from classes to interfaces between Hadoop 1
and 2.  Replaced them with calls to the associated helper methods on
the HadoopCompat interface.

Split titan-dist into Hadoop 1 and 2 submodules

Before this commit, Maven built one distribution zip/tar archive based
on Hadoop 2.  Now it generates a pair of archives, one for Hadoop 2
and another for Hadoop 1.  Each archive runs a separate execution of
the Expect-based integration tests.

Deprecating some Faunus config classes

These are probably going to be removed soon.

titan-hadoop-core, with a little bit of code in the Hadoop1Compat and
Hadoop2Compat layers to account for different config key names and
interface deprecations.

Increase timeout in titan-dist Cassandra tests

Add DistributedCache support in Faunus + Hadoop2

It's now possible to forego supplying a mapred job jar, in which case
Faunus under Hadoop 2 will iterate over all jars in the classpath and
call job.addFileToClassPath on each one, which puts them in the
DistributedCache and makes them available to the job at runtime.

This is only lightly tested.  It could also be generalized to Hadoop
1, although I'm not sure which types would be incompatible and which
can be shared and go in core.

Change some maven module descriptions

Technically this commit changes the <name/> tag in the poms of several
modules, but <name/> is just a human-friendly text string.  This
commit does not change any artifact or filenames.

Stop packaging test resources in the hadoop jars

titan-hadoop-1 and -2 needlessly included a couple of test resource
files along with their classfiles when packaging themselves.  Now
these test resources are omitted from their jars.

Create titan-hadoop "universal binary" jar

Similar to titan-hbase, titan-hadoop assembles the classfiles from
titan-hadoop-core, titan-hadoop-1, and titan-hadoop-2 into a single
jar.  The compat shim loader in titan-hadoop-core reflectively loads
classes from either titan-hadoop-2 or titan-hadoop-2 depending on what
version of Hadoop is detected at runtime.

This commit also updates titan-all and titan-dist to use the
titan-hadoop jar.

Fix and extend titan-dist tests

This commit should ideally be split up into smaller commits, but
overlapping changes in titan-dist/pom.xml made that difficult.

This commit fixes the existing Expect-based tests, all of which were
broken before this commit.  There were a couple of problems:

1. Vertex IDs assigned by Titan during even trivial gremlin.sh
examples have changed since the Expect tests were originally written,
so that the current vertex IDs disagree with the constants embedded in
the Expect scripts.  I replaced all of those constant vertex ID
expectations with regexes for nonnegative integers.

2. A mismatch between the config files generated in titan-dist/pom.xml
and the default config files used by CassandraStorageSetup prevented
Cassandra from even starting

Both of these are fixed.

This commit also adds three new tests of Faunus:

* graphson->cassandra, shutdown, then cassandra->graphson
* graphson->hbase, shutdown, then hbase->graphson
* graphson->graphson

The Cassandra tests run once on BOP and then again on Murmur.  The
HBase tests run against whatever HBase version is in the zipfile
(currently: 0.98).  The tests start HBase automatically using the test
harness in titan-hbase-parent.

This commit also disables batch-loading in the default
titan-hbase-output.properties and titan-cassandra-output.properties
files shipped in the zipfile.  This is a temporary workaround for the
schema inferencer not forcing batch-loading off.

This commit also adds hbase-server to the zipfile dependency tree.
The zipfile was originally written with 0.94, which just had a single
artifact named "hbase".  0.96 and 0.98 are split between the
"hbase-client" and "hbase-server" artifacts, and HBase's MapReduce
input format ships in the latter.  Failing to include it in the
zipfile produced ClassNotFoundException when attempting to use the
HBase input format.

Several sample Faunus config files included in the zipfile contain a
path to ./graph-of-the-gods.json.  I changed this to
example-data/graph-ofthe-gods.json, so that the example files work
without any modification or file copying when using MapReduce's local
(in-process) job runner and directly accessing the local filesystem.

The modification to the root-level pom.xml file resolves a dependency
conflict between rexster and hbase-server over grizzly2's exact
version number.

Hack support for HBase short CF names in Faunus

Prior to this commit, Faunus's HBase input format would fail to read
from a Titan database written with short-cf-names=true (currently the
default), since it just assumed that long CF names were in use.

This commit suggests future refactoring.  Hiding the mapping between
short and long names inside HBaseStoreManager a private datastructure
prevents TitanHBaseInputFormat from reading it.  Either the mapping
needs to become public, or we would need to change the type of CF
names from String to an enum or some interface that can supply both
the short and long name through a pair of methods.

Prevent avoidable NPE in TitanGraphOutputMR

TitanGraphOutputMapReduce has a static helper that constructs a
configuration with some default settings commonly used in testing.
These are Cassandra specific, which doesn't really belong in the
store-agnostic TitanGraphOutputMapReduce class anyway, but moving it
is a task for a future commit.  This commit just modifies the
default-setting logic to avoid an NPE when cassandra.yaml is not
available as a classloader resource in the same package as
TitanCassandraInputFormat.  That's still the first place it looks, but
if it comes up null, it tries the system classloader, and if that
comes up null, then it does not attempt to set a default value for the
cassandra.yaml path.

Make shared hadoop test resources dep optional

This changes titan-hadoop-2's dependency on titan-hadoop-core's
shared-resources jar to be both optional and test-scoped.  This change
only affects titan-hadoop-2.
Add shared test resources to titan-hadoop-1 build

Support external calls to titan-hbase test harness

The test support code in titan-hbase-core can start and stop HBase
daemons at several different supported versions.  Prior to this
commit, the harness assumed that the current working directory of the
process was one of the titan-hbase-parent/titan-hbase-09X/
directories.  Now the harness's assumption can be overridden by
setting the test.hbase.parentdir system property.  This supports reuse
of the HBase daemon test harness from other modules, such as
titan-dist.  It's not the cleanest way to do it, but it works for now.

Make Backend.clearStorage/.close idempotent

clearStorage already closes the Backend handles as it deletes their
data, so it doesn't make sense to call it multiple times.  Idempotence
of close is slightly more intuitive.

Make txs w/ locks write at QUORUM or higher

Along with cb8660102019c44288ee5556a8851b4307a211da and the tests
added by 7b159ef16be02f018053f6d0e0efa32809cdd8a9, this commit fixes
strong-consistency transaction both to read actual values associated
with expectations out of the backing store and to mutate data on the
backing store when at least one lock is held.

This commit also removes the warning added in
cb8660102019c44288ee5556a8851b4307a211da since it's now obsolete.

Adding test of EVCS transaction handling

EVCS = ExpectedValueCheckingStore and associated manager and
transaction classes.  These classes hold a transaction which is
supposed to provide global strong consistency and another transaction
which does not guarantee any particular level of consistency.  This
new test checks that the strong consistency tx is used when reading
data to check expectations and when writing mutations for a
transaction which has taken at least one lock.
Updated doc

Refactored KV interfaces to push down limit into the adapter and provide support for multi-query (the latter is still somewhat experimental since the test has no supporting implementation at this point).

single one of these tests with -Dit.test=....  The runner would
execute the method overload defined in the subclass twice (not once in

Major HBase test refactoring

This commit was prompted by test failures on titan-hbase-parent
following the TTL merge.  It's mostly a response to
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-10312.  On 0.94 and 0.98,
this was as simple as updating the HBase version, but 0.96 does not
have a fixed release yet, so this commit changes the tests to restart
HBase between each test class under 0.96.

Add hack for millisecond sleepPast method

Mutation code in the storage backends assume that it's safe to play
with the least significant bit of timestamp longs, masking it to zero
for deletions, or'ing one for additions.  This is safe at microsecond
and nanosecond resolution, but milliseconds are long enough that
masking the lsb (1 ms) can result in write corruption that takes the
form of "lost" operations in testing.  This change modifies the
sleepPast method called by the mutation logic to compensate.

Make HBase default to millisecond timestamps

Unless the graph configuration specifies a timestamp provider
resolution, HBase will now default to millisecond resolution.  The
point of this change is to support TTL on HBase, since TTL seems to
implicitly require currentTimeMillis-valued timestamps due to how TTL
is implemented on the server-side.

Let stores set a preferred timestamp resolution

This adds a new method to StoreFeatures named getPreferredTimestamps
that returns a Timestamps enum value (MILLI, MICRO, or NANO).

When freezing the graph config, core will honor the backend's
preference so long as hasTimestamps is true and the user-provided
configuration did not explicitly set TIMESTAMP_PROVIDER.

Fix bug in TIMESTAMP_PROVIDER definition

ConfigOptions store a type token representing the class or interface
of their values.  ConfigOption has a constructor that tries to guess
the type token by calling defaultValue.getClass().  Calling getClass()
on an enum value returns the class of that particular enum value,
which is likely to be an inner class identifier like EnumName$1.  This
is almost always not what the writer intended.

We might be able to change ConfigOption's constructor to check whether
the default value belongs to an enum, and then try to get the enum
class, but I'm not sure it's worth the complexity.  The user can
always specify the intended type token by invoking another constructor
overload.  I've done the latter with TIMESTAMP_PROVIDER.

This fixes a runtime exception whenever we attempted to set and then
lookup a non-default TIMESTAMP_PROVIDER config setting.

configuration for a while now.  storage.port is succinct but too

HBase shorthands were introduced and the short forms weren't updated.

Tweak gremlin.sh log config for HBase & MR

Using the HBase storage backend in gremlin.sh produced a ton of these
relatively uninteresting ZK log messages level:

INFO  org.apache.hadoop.hbase.zookeeper.RecoverableZooKeeper  - Process identifier=catalogtracker-on-hconnection-0x45f55321 connecting to ZooKeeper ensemble=127.0.0.1:2181

The default logger level is WARN, but I set the org.apache.hadoop
package prefix to INFO a while back by default so that MapReduce job
progress information would be visible.  This ZK noise is an unintended
side effect.

This commit narrows the INFO override to
org.apache.hadoop.{mapred,mapreduce}.  It's still possible to override
both the catchall level on the root logger and the level of the MR
packages via either the -l command line option to gremlin.sh or by
setting these environment variables:

 GREMLIN_LOG_LEVEL
 GREMLIN_MR_LOG_LEVEL

Add HBase short CF names for three families

These three CFs did not have short name mappings:

  system_properties_lock_
  systemlog
  txlog

This commit adds a single-character short name for each one.

Fix/expand default TitanGraph config for Hadoop

This commit increases latency tolerance in the default TitanGraph
configuration used by titan-hadoop.  The diff shows exactly which
options are set, but the general idea is to increase timeouts and
retries.  It also sets the buffer-size to Integer.MAX_VALUE to prevent
Titan from chunking a single commit's mutations into multiple
HTable.batch or Cassandra.Client.batch_mutate calls.

This commit also exposed some outdated & hardcoded config option
strings in TitanGraphOutputMapReduce.

Fix titan-all dependency problems

This commit makes two changes in titan-all's dependency tree:

1. titan-all now depends on hbase-client 0.98.2-hadoop2.  Before, it
   didn't depend on an hbase/hbase-client version, relying on the user
   to set one or exclude the titan-hbase module in their own pom.
   titan-all now sets a default version to avoid
   NoClassDefFoundErrors.  Downstream poms can override or exclude it
   as desired.

2. titan-all now explicitly declares dependencies on the Jackson 1.x
   and 2.y artifacts that it indirectly uses.  titan-all doesn't
   directly use Jackson, but its transitive deps do.  Furthermore,
   those transitive deps brought in a combination of 1.8 and 1.9 jars,
   and this led to NoClassDefFoundErrors at runtime.  Now titan-all
   sets all the affected artifacts to the same version declared in
   dependencyManagement.

   Importing dependencyManagement might be the cleaner approach:

   http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html#Importing_Dependencies

   However, I'm wary of imposing additional requirements on downstream
   poms that want to use titan-all.  Also, I don't know whether
   dependencyManagement imports work on non-Maven tools that parse
   poms, such as gradle or sbt.  The approach in this commit is
   stupider than dependencyManagement imports but also simpler and
   should work regardless of the tool manipulating the downstream pom.

Make ReflectiveConfigOptionLoader more robust

Related: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/aureliusgraphs/FD5cKy72h7Y

ReflectiveConfigOptionLoader walks the classpath at startup, looking
for static ConfigOption fields to initialize.  titan-all depends on
titan-hbase, but it leaves declaration of an hbase-client dependency
to the user.  titan-hbase's classes won't actually link without an
hbase-client jar available.  If the user doesn't provide one, then
ReflectiveConfigOptionLoader will walk over HBaseStoreManager's
ConfigOption fields and die with linkage errors on org.apache.hbase
when trying to load HBaseStoreManager and initialize its fields.

ReflectiveConfigOptionLoader now catches and warns on linkage errors
it encounters while walking the classpath instead of propagating them
up the stack.

titan-all still needs to depend on hbase-client.  Right now,
declaration of a dependency on hbase-client is left up to the user;
this is too brittle.  Better to set a dependency on some version than
none at all, leading to classpath problems if the user doesn't declare
an HBase dep.  That will happen in a follow-up commit.

Cleanup titan-hbase source/javadoc jar creation

Prior to this commit, titan-hbase's javadoc jar was built by copying
the source files for the titan-hbase-core and -09X modules into a
single directory, then invoking maven-javadoc-plugin on the directory.
This worked, but maven-javadoc-plugin would fill the console with
scary-looking though harmless warnings since it couldn't resolve any
of the imports in the source files.  The point of this commit is
basically to avoid those warnings.  The titan-hbase javadoc jar is now
built via an assembly that unpacks the titan-hbase-core javadoc.  This
is kind of a downgrade, since the javadoc no longer includes the
compat shim classes in the titan-hbase-09X modules, but there's not
much interesting content to javadoc in there anyway.  We could get
them back by creating yet another module, but we already have so
many...

Fix configuration for Hadoop 2 combiners

This commit fixes a failsafe integration test failure in
TitanCassandraOutputFormatTest#testBulkEdgeDerivations that occurred
on titan-hadoop-2 but not on titan-hadoop-1.  The link step was
failing with an NPE when attempting to read the traversal direction
from the config under H2 (but succeeding under H1).  I think this is
due to the way Hadoop2Compiler handles job configuration; it sets
custom config keys, including the traversal direction for link steps,
on the reducer and mapper but not on the combiner.  This commit tries
to pull the custom config keys up to the job level so that they're
inherited by the combiner as well as the reducer and mapper.  At
least, I think that's what's going on -- not 100% confident I've got
the analysis correct, even though the fix seems to work.

Add ConfigNamespace/ConfigOption to titan-hadoop

This commit introduces a ConfigNamespace and several ConfigOptions to
titan-hadoop and replaces several hardcoded string keys scattered
around the code with ConfigOption uses.

This is not a complete migration away from Hadoop Configuration.  A
few of the unresolved issues:

* Hadoop Configuration's setClass(String key, Class impl, Class iface)
  method does not have an exact equivalent in the titan-core
  configuration API.  It could be modeled with ConfigOptions
  parameterized in a composite value representing a pair of impl and
  iface, but that's not ideal.

* Hadoop Configurations are unavoidable when working with MR, so I
  took the approach extending Hadoop's Configured base class with a
  HybridConfigured subclass that maintains both a Hadoop Configuration
  and read-only Titan configuration backed by the Hadoop
  Configuration.  All writes currently have to go though the Hadoop
  Configuration though, and that's cumbersome in some places.

* Several input and output format-specific options haven't been
  migrated to ConfigOption at all (e.g. rdf and edgelist options)

Major Hadoop module refactoring

This commit reintroduces the titan-hadoop-core module last seen in
3a16ea2f48fbcd8bbe74884d982ef8a39e9535fd.  The core module compiles
against the same Hadoop 2.x version as the titan-hadoop-2 module, so
in the event of an oversight failure on our part that leaks a
bytecode-level Hadoop1/2 incompatibility into titan-hadoop-core, only
the titan-hadoop-1 module will break.

This is technically inferior to the strategy used prior to this
commit.  That approach had no titan-hadoop-core module.  The
titan-hadoop-1 and titan-hadoop-2 modules shared each used the build
helper plugin to add a common source directory to the build path, so
that they had one directory containing hadoop1/2-specific sources and
also had the common source directory.  The titan-hadoop-1 and -2
modules compiled every source file using their target Hadoop library
version.  This is nice because it precludes classfile linkage errors
at runtime, but the downside is that neither Eclipse m2e nor IDEA are
capable of comprehending this Maven configuration, rendering them
little more than red-colored text editors on the modules in question.

Contrast this with the approach in this commit, where
titan-hadoop-core is compiled against a Hadoop 2 jar, and it's on us
to keep out IncompatibleClassChange-inducing ABI incompatibilites.
This raises the possibility of runtime classfile linkage errors, but
the upshot is that both Eclipse and IDEA can understand it.

This commit makes a few other changes:

* deleted BlueprintsGraphOutputMapReduce and replaced calls to its
  static methods with equivalent static calls on
  TitanGraphOutputMapReduce

* deleted BlueprintsGraphOutputMapReduceTest; there is some test logic
  in here that would be nice to port to Titan, but replacing
  TinkerGraph with Titan without breaking/rewriting the test seemed
  nontrivial

* Shortened some config keys:

Refactor EVCS lock-checking logic

This change is mostly a refactoring and javadoc commit in the
ExpectedValueChecking* classes.

However, it also includes a functional change.  Previous to this
commit, locks taken on stores without any mutations (stores treated as
read-only) would be ignored.  Now locks are checked regardless of
whether the underlying store has any data mutations waiting.
Merge branch 'titan05' of github.com:thinkaurelius/titan into titan05

Fix locking bug in ExpectedValueChecking*

ExpectedValueCheckingTransactions with locks on more than one store
only checked locks on one of the stores at mutation time and ignored
locks on the rest of the stores.  This affected Titan when it called
EVCSManager.mutateMany after acquiring locks on multiple stores.  It
could also have theoretically affected Titan if it called EVCS.mutate
on different stores but using the same transaction, though I don't
know whether core contains any such cases -- just that the potential
to exercise the bug would exist there.

Fix bug in ExpectedValueCheckingTx

EVCT calls getSlice with bounds [col, nextBiggerBuffer(col)), where
col is given by the caller.  This slice returns exact matches of col,
if present in the backend, but it can also return longer columns for
which col is a prefix.  This is a bug -- EVCT should be responsible
for ignoring columns which aren't an exact match of col provided by
the caller.

This manifested as a bug in
ThriftGraphCacheTest#testGraphConfiguration which actually had nothing
to do with db-cache.  The problem was that ECVT was considering both
values for "cache.db-cache" and "cache.db-cache-time" when attempting
to lock and check "cache.db-cache", causing a nonsensical
PermanentLockingException.

Expand titan-hadoop's Tokens implementation

The Tokens class formerly loaded a resource named version.txt from the
classpath, then read a single line containing the runtime version.

version.txt is now known as meta.properties, and it contains a
Java-Properties-formatted set of key-value pairs.  The current keys
are version and jobjar.  The latter key is the name of the default
mapred job jar.  Making this dynamic instead of hard-coded allows the
hadoop1 and hadoop2 artifacts to have different job jars without
potential for overwriting or mixups stemming from having two job jars
with identical names but different contents and Hadoop major versions.

Refatoring titan-hadoop into -hadoop1 and -hadoop2

Faunus/Titan-Hadoop is now two separate artiacts with different
classifiers.  The user's expected to choose the appropriate
classifier.

This commit retains the reflective instantiation chicanery from my
previous commit's all-in-one attempt.  That could be simplified away
in future commits.

One particular test, BlueprintsGraphOutputMapReduceTest, is completely
broken in this commit and I'm still not sure why.  It's got a
nonsensical Hadoop filesystem configuration issue and a scary-looking
type error involving a Mockito synthetic object.  Something is
seriously wrong with that test (and potentially indicative of a wider
problem), but I'm not sure what.

Refactoring titan-hadoop for multiversion support

This is an attempt to refactor the titan-hadoop module to
transparently support both Hadoop1 and Hadoop2 using a reflective shim
loader, similar to the way Hive and titan-hbase hide details related
to the specific version of Hadoop and HBase, respectively.

However, this is probably going to be more trouble than it's worth.
There's too much API leakage in titan-hadoop-core; besides Hadoop's
Counter class sustaining incompatible changes between versions,
several of the test classes wont even load in a Hadoop1 CLASSPATH
after being compiled against Hadoop2.  Instead of spending a bunch of
time trying to isolate every incompatible change and move it into the
shims (which is possible but time consuming), I'm probably going to
just produce two different artifacts, one with a hadoop1 classifier
and the other with a hadoop2 classifier.

Improve edge case in HBase's ensureTableExists

This method assumed that the table was enabled.  If the table was
already disabled for some reason -- say, because Titan was killed
before it could completely setup schema the first time it was executed
-- then this method would fail unnecessarily.  Now the method checks
whether the table is already enabled.  Besides this check, if the
method catches a TableNotEnabledException when disabling, it now logs
the and proceeds as usual instead of propagating it up the stack.

Fixup log4j configuration shipped in deb/rpm pkgs

Now /etc/titan/log4j.properties exists and is respected by Rexster.

This file sets up a rolling file appender with date-and-timestamps.
These stamps include the yyyy-mm-dd date and the time of day to the
milliseconds place.  The default Rexster log4j configuration does not
include any kind of time or datestamp and I think one is sorely needed
for the rpm/deb distribution.

Implementation note: the only way to get Rexster to use a log4j config
is to either put it in a file named "log4j.properties" in the current
working directory of the JVM or to pack it in rexster's own jar so
that it will load when Rexster calls
Application.class.getResource("log4j.properties").  This behavior is
hardcoded into a static initializer in Rexster's Application class and
it overrides the default log4j configuration mechanism.  I would
rather use the default log4j mechanism but changing Rexster's behavior
is out-of-scope.

This commit makes the Cassandra-backed LogTest subclasses run serially

Create HBase table before reading rowkey partition

This avoids a nonfatal but scary-looking exception when Titan is
opened against a HBase cluster for the first time.  The
HBaseStoreManager didn't check that Titan's table existed when reading
the rowkey partitions for the table.  It would attempt to lookup
rowkey bounds for a nonexistent table, leading to a
TableNotFoundException.  It would proceed to create the table and this
wouldn't occur on subsequent opens.

This should be fixed, since getLocalKeyPartition() now ensures that
the table exists before trying to read its rowkey bounds.
Minor pom formatting tweak

Refactor HBase modules to play nice with IDEA

Both IDEA and Eclipse are unable to to handle Maven
<testSourceDirectory/> or a build-helper-maven-plugin:add-test-source
config pointed at a directory outside the module basedir.  Shuffling
tests into titan-hbase-core and packaging them into a test-jar to work
around this limitation.

This commit also fixes the bogus packagename declaration at the top of
HBaseStatus.java.
Tweak HBase and Cassandra test log configs

Remove potential race in CKIDManager

Got this exception on a EC2 Bamboo build.  I can't reproduce it, but
it's concerning, since it suggests a block was erroneously allocated
twice in the IDAuthority stress test under HBase:

28-May-2014 23:16:44 	Tests run: 18, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 346.307 sec <<< FAILURE! - in com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.hbase.HBaseIDAllocationTest
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	testMultiIDAcquisition[0](com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.hbase.HBaseIDAllocationTest)  Time elapsed: 75.904 sec  <<< FAILURE!
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	java.lang.AssertionError: null
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	        at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:86)
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	        at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:41)
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	        at org.junit.Assert.assertFalse(Assert.java:64)
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	        at org.junit.Assert.assertFalse(Assert.java:74)
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.IDAllocationTest.checkBlock(IDAllocationTest.java:179)
28-May-2014 23:16:44 	        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.IDAllocationTest.testMultiIDAcquisition(IDAllocationTest.java:390)

I think this happened because the timestamp used in the ID allocation
write is generated prior to starting the IDAUTHORITY_WAIT timer.  If a
thread generates its timestamp, then gets pulled off core by the OS
scheduler, then gets placed back on a core and proceeds to start the
IDAUTHORITY_WAIT timer, it could potentially end up writing a
timestamp older than IDAUTHORITY_WAIT without triggering a retry.  At
least, that's my best guess for what happened.
Clean Maven Shade's temp file in HBase 0.94 build

Fix cached_classpath generation for `mvn package`

`mvn install` worked fine for all HBase builds, but running the
`package` (which does not install Titan artifacts in the local
repository, just builds jars) would fail due to the way the HBase test
daemon's cached_classpath.txt file was generated.  This is fixed.

Rewrite HBase test daemon start/stop logic

The shutdown hook usually executes on my machine, but every so often
it would not fire before the forked test VM died, causing later HBase
module test suites to hang.  I think this commit prevents that
behavior by checking for a "leftover" running HBase daemon before
starting the test suite.

Unify and shorten BDB test names

Rename classes to remove "Internal" anachronism

During the earliest stages of Titan's test harness development, we
named Cassandra tests with either the prefix "Internal" or "External"
depending on whether the test was responsible for bootstrapping its
own Cassandra instance for testing purposes or whether it could assume
a Cassandra instance was already listening on localhost and the
default Thrift port, respectively.  The Cassandra test harness has
matured since then; the "External" test classes have long since been
removed, but the naming scheme left a legacy of superfluous "Internal"
prefixes all over titan-cassandra's src/test/java.

I've stripped the "Internal" anachronism and removed the last mentions
to the External/Internal distinction from the top-level pom.xml.

I also used this opportunity to shorten some of the the obscenely long
Cassandra test class names; for example

  InternalCassandraEmbeddedMultiWriteKeyColumnValueStoreTest

is now just

  EmbeddedMultiWriteStoreTest

The other backends don't have the External/Internal naming
anachronism, but I'm planning to shorten them according to the same
pattern in a subsequent commit.

Fix regression in LogTest$MessagePuller

The most important change in this commit fixes a regression that I
introduced yesterday via 7da161f9d8f2ef9f3384abcc97794df63c00412b.
Specifically, it broke the calculation of the end of MessagePuller's
column slice bounds by allowing them to straddle two timeslices.
Timeslices are mapped 1-to-1 with keys, and each individual
MessagePuller run is only supposed to query one timeslice/key.  The
regression manifested as dropping messages in the broken column slice
belonging that belonged to the later of the two timeslices.

This commit also introduces a bunch of new logging output and a
toString() implementation that I used when investigating the
regression and which will probably be useful in future debugging.

This makes the LogTest implementations a bit more responsive

Tweak titan-cassandra log4j test config

This replaces milliseconds-since-logger-was-created with yyyy-mm-dd
hh:mm:ss.SSS.  The point of this change is to make comparison of times

This also adds some commented lines that can be uncommented to enable
lots of DEBUG-level output in KCVSLog's implementation and tests
(under Cassandra).

Create HBase compat shim ConfigOption

checks in favor of an ordinary graph configuration option,

Modified ReadMarker.fromNow() semantics

Prior to this commit, I was still seeing occasional nondeterministic
LogTest failures where some messages would be written to the store but
never read by a MessagePuller.  I think these failures were due to
ReadMarker.fromNow() and maxTime jointly creating a MessagePuller
slice window strictly later than the "lost" messages.  I've changed
ReadMarker.fromNow() to use the time at the moment the static method
is invoked, rather than when the associated MessagePuller initializes,
and I also changed the MessagePuller's maxTime computation.

Introduce HBase shim override option

Setting TITAN_HBASE_COMPAT_CLASS (in either the JVM system properties
or the process environment) to a full package and classname of a
HBaseCompat implementation overrides Titan's HBase version detection
in favor of reflectively instantiating an instance of the named class
and casting it to HBaseCompat.

HBase/Cassandra read op timestamp tweaks

This commit mostly affects read timestamps used by the Cassandra
embedded adapter, which could previously break reads on columns with
TTLs set when Titan was configured for a timestamp resolution other
than milliseconds.

All of the HBase and Cassandra backends should continue to retrieve
the most recent version of rows/columns, regardless of
TransactionHandleConfig.getStartTime().  The notion of start time is
generally not practical when using native HBase and Cassandra
timestamps, since Cassandra only shows the most recent column version
and HBase retains only between 1 and 3 most recent versions under its
default configuration (and may well be configured to retain only 1).

There's also some minor refactoring in DistributedStoreManager; I
renamed "Timestamp" to "MaskedTimestamp" in an attempt to highlight
this class's sole function, which is to encapsulate some bitmask
operations on otherwise ordinary timestamps.

There is more timestamp refactoring to come after this commit; this
just focuses on some delicate changes in the Cassandra embedded
adapter and refactoring in DistributedStoreManager.(Masked)Timestamp
and its usage sites.

"gremlin>" prompt, the return value prefix "==>", string literals, and

This config includes a local file:/// path that's only valid on my
system (in titansingle.xsl).  This is due to a limitation in xslthl;
it needs to be told where its config file is, but it can only process
either http:// or absolute file:// values, not relative paths.  I'm
probably going to end up filtering that stylesheet through
maven-resources-plugin so that I can substitute an absolute path based
on Maven's ${project.basedir} property.

Switch to HTML 4.01 Transitional and DocBook 5

The current latest version of the AsciiDoctor maven plugin defaults to
DocBook version 4.5.  According to this issue, AsciiDoctor's default
DocBook version is changing to 5.0 in AsciiDoctor 1.5.0 (which has not
yet been released):

  https://github.com/asciidoctor/asciidoctor/issues/554

This commit forces docbook5 generation on the current AsciiDoctor
plugin by setting the backend to "docbook5".  This commit also
modifies htcust.xsl to generate HTML with the 4.01 Transitional
DOCTYPE and set the output encoding to utf-8.  The generated HTML
currently validates on http://validator.w3.org/check.  I also turned
on indentation in the HTML generator.

Initial AsciiDoc -> DocBook -> XHTML mvn toolchain

In this commit, `mvn -N -Psaxondoc package xml:transform` builds the
AsciiDoc source docs/index.txt into a DocBook file,
`target/generated-docs/index.xml`, which is then transformed with
Saxon using the xslthl extension for syntax highlighting to produce
the XHTML document `target/generated-resources/xml/xslt/index.xml`.

common.xsl is taken from AsciiDoc; htcust.xml is a half-page so-called
"customization layer" stylesheet that glues together common.xsl with
xslthl highlighting.

This is the earliest proof-of-concept stage.  Much work remains in
both tweaking the XHTML style to fit with the new Titan website and in
porting the existing wikidocs to AsciiDoc before this could be
considered ready for distribution.

Updated persistence to store the full entry on deletion so that this information is available in the transaction log.

Refactored the commit in StandardTitanGraph to be more robust and include the trigger log in the commit phase.
We now log the status of the entire transaction in the transaction log and record at what stage a transaction failed. This should make it possible to reconstruct a consistent state from the log.
Also using a partition key for the transaction log so that all log entries for a transaction are guaranteed to end up in the same partition of the log.
Changed the order of commit and rollback for higher robustness and introduced extra log messages.
Added commit time and userTimestamp to transaction configuration to disembiguate the two.
Added transaction meta data to log needed to re-create the transaction.

Rewrite titan.sh to start ES as a separate process

In addition to the summary above, this commit adds blocking logic
after forking Rexster and ES during `titan.sh start`.  Now the script
waits until it can successfully connect to port 9300 (after starting
ES) and 8184 (after starting Rexster) before returning.

Helper program that tries a socket connection

I'm adding this to support titan.sh in the zipfile distribution.
titan.sh ideally wants to wait until Elasticsearch is completely
started and listening on its service port before attempting to start
Rexster.  It would also be convenient to wait until Rexster is
accepting connections on the RexPro port before returning from
titan.sh; titan.sh currently just forks Rexster and returns
immediately, which leaves a window of a few seconds after titan.sh
exits but before Rexster is fully initialized in which the user can
start rexster-console.sh and get a transient connection refusal error.
The Rexster thing is not as big a deal as the ES-before-Rexster thing
though.

Anyway, this commit is inelegant: for one thing, there are existing,
widely-available programs that I would rather use than write my own
util (e.g. telnet, nc, socat, netstat, nmap... any one of them could
fill the need in this case).  However, I don't want to introduce a new
command dependency into titan.sh if I can reasonably avoid it, and I
think this qualifies as reasonable.  CheckSocket also doesn't really
belong in titan-core, but I don't have another place to put it without
restructuring the titan-dist module just for this one source file.

Adding ES config files to Titan zipfile

This prepares the zipfile to switch from embedded ES to standalone ES.
The files in this commit are based on the upstream ES 1.1.1 release,
but they have a few customizations:

* configured relative paths starting with "db/" in elasticsearch.yml

* elasticsearch.in.sh changes directory to the top-level directory of
  the expanded zipfile.  This supports the relative paths in the
  previous bullet.

* added '-Des.path.conf=...' JVM parameter in the elasticsearch shell
  script that points it at the "conf" subfolder.  ES uses "config" by
  default, but we currently call that directory "conf" (as does
  Cassandra).

Flip broken VertexIDAssignerTest partition bounds

Fixes #591

VertexIDAssignerTest uses a MockIDAuthority that takes its partition
bounds as an integer array of length 2, then writes the ints to
StaticBuffers in its getLocalIDPartition() method.  A precondition in
this method checks that the lower buffer compares before the upper
buffer.

VertexIDAssignerTest is a JUnit parameterized test, and one parameter
set passed the int array { -10000, 10000 } to MockIDAuthority.  This
was guaranteed to fail the precondition mentioned above, since the
negative int has the MSB set and the positive int doesn't.  This
showed up as an IllegalArgumentException in
titan-test/target/test.log.

I think this bug was limited to MockIDAuthority and
VertexIDAssignerTest.  I don't see how it could affect
VertexIDAssigner or ConsistentKeyIDManager.  CKIM works in terms of
opaque bytes.  VertexIDAssigner does work with ints, but it
unsigned-shifts them down two bits before doing any comparisons,
discarding the lower order bits and guaranteeing that the resulting
int values are positive.
First, simple per-edge TTL implementation

Rewrite javadoc for KCVS.getLocalKeyPartition()

Experimental Cassandra 2.0 support

This commit does not preserve backwards compatibility with Cassandra
1.2.  It's a quick feasibility test for 2.0 client-side support.

* Invasive source changes are required in the embedded adapter, in
  particular with explicit timestamp handling, but the embedded tests
  pass

* Thrift adapter required only one small change: a public static
  String field storing the name of the system keyspace in a Cassandra
  internals class has moved

* Astyanax adapter is broken with no apparent upgrade path.  Astyanax
  does not yet support Cassandra 2.0 on the client side, except
  perhaps in the unreleased beta Java driver branch.  Linkage errors
  at runtime when running against 2.0

* The Guava version is delicate.  Going to 16.0 or newer breaks
  Cassandra 2.0.x, which was compiled against Guava 13.x.  16.0
  changed the return type of
  com.google.common.util.concurrent.RateLimiter.acquire(int) from void
  to double, and that causes linkage errors with Cassandra at runtime.

Use dynamically loaded HBase compatibility layer

titan-hbase-core now dynamically instantiates one of two
implementations of the HBaseCompat interface depending on what version
string HBase's VersionInfo class reports.  There's one implementation
for 0.94 and one implementation for 0.96.  This approach is directly
inspired by Apache Hive's ShimLoader, which does something similar to
mask minor incompatibilities between different Hadoop versions.

The next critical step in this refactoring would be to write an
assembly that includes all of titan-hbase-094, -096, and -core in one
jar.

The titan-hbase-096 and -094 modules both appear to pass their tests
on my machine.

Fix IDAllocationTest UNIQUE_INSTANCE_ID generation

IDAuthority instances that required distinct UNIQUE_INSTANCE_ID values
were given identical ones in the IDAllocationTest setup methods,
leading to technically nondeterministic but extremly likely failures
in testMultiIDAcquisition.

This commit adds a pair of new tests: one that enforces the
UNIQUE_INSTANCE_ID distinctness constraint, and another that
stresstests a single IDAuthority instance and partition with
concurrent block requests from different threads.

This commit also refactors the IDAllocationTest to remove the
vestigial openStorageManager method parameter.  None of the
implementations of the method actually use it anymore.

All tests pass on my machine.

Experimental util to override config opts in tests

I often want to set higher lock wait and id allocation wait times when
running tests on EC2 m1.mediums running CI, since Cassandra writes
that take 175 ms seem common (1/2 of test runs?  eyeballing a list of
recent runs, not being rigorous here), but that's an excessive wait
time on my workstation.  I'm adding an experimental test utility class
that reads a config file path (possibly relative path) from an
environment variable and reads a config from the file.  Test classes
where overridden config settings could be useful (anything that's
timeout sensitive) can pass a WriteConfiguration to the utility class
to have the overrides applied.

Initially tried to used MergedConfiguration but went insane trying to
navigate the configuration type hierarchy.  Gave up after an hour and
went with modifying a single WriteConfiguration.

Skip backoff when exhausting ID uniqueid

Uniqueid exhaustion within a partition has nothing to do with backend
workload.  At most, we should wait the default backoff before
retrying; an increasing backoff is definitely not warranted.  This
commit removes any sort of backoff after an ID allocation attempt in
which all storage backend requests succeed but the uniqueid turns out
to be exhausted.

Suppress HConnectionManager exception warning

The method HConnectionManager.createConnection throws a narrower class
of of Exceptions in 0.94 and a wider class (proper superset of types)
in 0.96.  Catch the wider set and silence a warning about exception
hiding that appears when compiling against 0.94.

Refactor HBase connection handling

Now HBase manager is 1-to-1 with HConnection.  Each manager creates
its single HConnection during construction and assigns it to a final
field.  However, every method is responsible for calling
connection.getTable(String) and closing the returned table object in a
finally block.  These HTableInterface instances on the stack are not
thread safe.  The HConnection is only closed when the manager is
closed.

Compared to creating an HConnection on the stack each method, this
approach is faster and does not cause too many open files errors
during testing.

Naive HBase deprecation fix

This removes references to now-deprecated HBase API methods.  However,
it uses the simple approach to connection pooling recommended by the
HConnectionManager API @
http://hbase.apache.org/apidocs/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/client/HConnectionManager.html.

The problem with this is twofold:

* it's very slow -- even a tiny lock write takes on average 125 ms on
  my test machine, perhaps because of the heavyweight setup inside
  HConnection's implementation, which includes creating an executor

* my use of the HConnectionManager API may be leaking connections,
  because midway through the 0.94 test suite, the tests start dying
  with "Too many open files" when attempting to instantiate
  org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxnSocketNIO
Adding debug log msgs around storage failures

Refactored HBase region count configuration

Added a new option, regions-per-server, that takes effect if
region-count is unset.  When it takes effect, Titan's table is created
with total region count = (number of servers reported by HBase
ClusterStatus) * (regions-per-server).

If neither option is set, then the HBase manager still calls
HBaseAdmin#createTable(String) without specifying any rowkey
boundaries or region count.
Change MapR ZK version to 3.4.5

Refactor ID partitioning configuration

Deleted IDPartitionMode enum.  ids.partition is now a boolean again.
If it is not present in the kcvs configuration, then it is set to
features.isKeyOrdered() && features.isDistributed() just prior to
freezing

Add HBase region presplit support

The HBase backend does the following when creating the Titan table:

* check whether the storage.region-count config option is set to an
  integer greater than or equal MIN_REGION_COUNT (3), and if so, use
  that value, or if not...

* attempt to retrieve a ClusterStatus object from HBaseAdmin and count
  the number of servers, and if that's greater than MIN_REGION_COUNT,
  then use that, or if not...

* call the createTable(String) method in the HBase API without
  specifying the number of regions, allowing the HBase implementation
  to apply its own internal default value

I didn't realize MIN_REGION_COUNT would be necessary until I tried
setting region-count to 1, at which point HBase rejected my
createTable call with an exception.  I also found this:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-8170.

Fix HBase local key partition end bounds

My initial commit needlessly incremented the end key of each range
produced by the HBase API.  I thought this was necessary from the
javadoc, but in testing, it seems the keys returned are already
exclusive.  Either that or HBase is producing regions with a single
rowkey overlap on each end...

Fix BufferUtil.nextBiggerBuffer overflow handling

These options now do nothing under HBase except log warnings.  The

Fix bogus HBaseGraphMetrics test failure

When I enabled ID partitioning by default on HBase, it switched from
initializing a single ID pool to 10, the default value of
SimpleBulkPlacementStrategy.CONCURRENT_PARTITIONS.  This caused
HBaseGraphMetricsTest#testKCVSAccess1 to fail when counting the number
of getSlice calls made by a graphdb instance, since initializing those
extra pools requires more getSlices.

Handle zero upper partition bounds

VertexIDAssigner reads the first four bytes of key ranges provided by
getLocalKeyPartition as ints.  It then unsigned right shifts the ints
by two bits each to make them effectively 30 bits wide.  It does some
arithmetic on the ints to preserve inclusive-start and exclusive-end
semantics and then passes them to PartitionIDRange's constructor.

Here's the computation done on each range-end int:

  partition[1] = (partition[1] >>> 2) - 1;

If the original partition[1] value is 0, this results in
Integer.MIN_VALUE.  Because the partition width is 30 bits, this value
is invalid (too wide since the MSB is set).  This value leads to a
precondition failure shortly after in PartitionIDRange's constructor.

I think the intent is to follow the subtraction by zeroing the two
most significant bits, simulating 30-bit wide unsigned integer
arithmetic and allowing underflow.  So this commit adds a bitmask
after subtraction like so:

  partition[1] = (partition[1] >>> 2) - 1;
  partition[1] &= 0x3FFFFFFF;

Rewrite HBase's getLocalKeyPartition

This theoretically does the necessary length padding and endKey binary
arithmetic necessary to convert from HBase's startkey/endkey
convention to Titan ID partitioning conventions, but it is almost
totally untested.

Break some &&'d Preconditions into multiple calls

Precondition boolean expressions with && conjunctions are ambiguous
without a detailed error message, since it's not possibe to tell which
clauses were false.  I separated a few instances of this around ID
partitioning handling into multiple Preconditions calls for the same
correctness guarantees but with less ambiguity and slightly increased
overhead cost.

Refactor ID Partitioning configuration

Instead of a boolean, ID partitioning is now a three-valued enum:

* DEFAULT
* ENABLED
* DISABLED

ENABLED corresponds to the old value of true, and DISABLED corresponds
to the old value of false.  DEFAULT is the new behavior.  This enables
partitioning if the backend store reports isKeyOrdered() &&
isDistributed() via its StoreFeatures.  Otherwise partitioning is
disabled.

A warning is logged if the user sets DISABLED but the DEFAULT feature
criteria are true.

Setting exponential growth in getIDBlock backoff

Failures in getIDBlock now cause the method to wait for a backoff
period that doubles with every failure, starting at
idApplicationWaitMS and capped at 16 * idApplicationWaitMS.  This
gives six steps total (1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32).

Renaming idauthority-retries to match new purpose

The consistent key ID manager will now retry an allocation as many
times as possible before its timeout argument elapses;
idauthority-retries is now idauthority-uniqueid-retries and limits
only the number of randomized unique ids Titan tries within a
partition before assuming the whole partition is exhausted.
Deleting old commented method from IDAuthority

Adding timeout parameter to IDAuthority#getIDBlock

Instead of relying on a hardcoded retry count, getIDBlock now takes a
timeout long and accompanying TimeUnit.  Implementations return if
they are unable to allocate a block within the timeout duration.  But
really only the ConsistentKeyIDManager implementation respects the
timeout; MockIDManager doesn't bother.

I think idApplicationRetryCount could be refactored with a more
descriptive name now, since its only function is to limit the number
of randomized unique id exhaustions allowed before declaring the whole
partition exhausted.

Fix minor concurrency bug in IDPoolTest

Now that IDPoolTest threads actually run in parallel instead of
serially (78b9a0af2e60db3ae841ccbfafe2393d0b56f030), they've run
across a problem in MockIDAuthority.  Its getIDBlock method is
instance-synchronized, but it needs to be concurrently accessed by
multiple threads.  When delayAcquisitionMS is nonzero, this can result
in unlucky threads waiting 2 or 3 times the delayAcquistionMS period
and the enclosing test throwing an unexpected exception.

I tweaked MockIDAuthority's constructors to make the
delayAcquisitionMS variable final, squinted at the getIDBlock
implementation for a while looking for anything else thread-unsafe
(found nothing), and then removed the synchronized modifier.

Make IDPoolTest parallel

IDPoolTest creates an array of Threads.  It then iterates over the
array, first calling run (not start), and the iterates a second time
calling join.

Because the context contains joins on all these threads, I suspect
calling run was a mistake and start was intended.  I've modified the
line in question.
Shutdown executor in StandardIDPool.close()

Expose ID renewal exceptions to client

Exceptions in the ID renewer ("IDBlockThread") which previously were
invisible to the Titan client, appearing only as uncaught exceptions
on stderr, are now passed up to the client using Future.get().

closes #527
Fix bug in Timestamps.MICRO.sleepUntil

Add general sleep-after-mutate method

HBase already slept after mutating, but now instead of sleeping for a
hardcoded millisecond it sleeps for a time based on its
TimestampProvider (but falls back to 1 ms if no provider is set).

Cassandra could get away without this method in its mutate
implementations back when it used nanotime, but with millisecond
resolution (Timestamps.MILLI or .MICRO providers), some of the tests
routinely fail because multiple operations are colliding inside a
single millisecond (MultiWrite especially).

Adding sleep after mutate back into HBase

Though this probably isn't necessary on a large deployment where the
HBase endpoint is on a machine physically separate from the Titan
machine, I just got an error in pseudocluster mode testing where
everything is local.  Not worth introducing a race to save one
millisecond per mutate.

Support configurable HBase timestamp resolution

* the HBase diskstorage code now uses transaction-provided timestamps

* ConsistentKeyIDManager has gone back to using the value of
  GraphDatabaseConfiguration.TIMESTAMP_PROVIDER on the graph config,
  instead of using milliseconds everywhere, due to the next change...

* HBase's clearStorage() method now looks at the first row and column
  returned by its scanner and guesses the timestamp resolution based
  on magnitude.  This means clearStorage() will not work with
  arbitrary user-supplied timestamps, but only with millisecond,
  microsecond, or nanosecond timestamps based on UNIX Epoch.  I would
  prefer to use HBase's recommended truncation method of disabling the
  table, deleting it, and recreating it, but when I tried it, that
  roughly quadrupled the runtime of the test suite.

* eliminated some unused methods from HBaseKCVS

* removed the sleep following writes in HBaseStoreManager's
  mutateMany method

* added explicit timestamp bounds to HBase read command objects

Make hardcoded nanotime use configurable in CKL

Found a bunch of hardcoded references to TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS as soon
as I tried microsecond time in ConsistentKeyLocker; this commit passes
the test suite

in GraphDatabaseConfiguration instead of just defaulting to nanotime

Timestamp-related refactoring in core

* Combined NanoTime and MicroTime classes into a single enum called
  Timestamps.  The TimestampProvider interface is unchanged.

* Added a TIMESTAMP_PROVIDER ConfigOption to
  GraphDatabaseConfiguration and made StandardTransactionBuilder apply
  its value.  The default is micros.

* Made ConsistentKeyIDManager use millisecond timestamps in its mutate
  calls.  Before this commit, it seemed to write columns containing
  millisecond time but issue those writes to Cassandra/HBase using
  nanotime at the protocol level.  Now it should be milliseconds
  throughout.

* Made ConsistentKeyIDManager instantiate a new storage transaction
  configuration for each mutate call.

* Cleaned up a couple cases of commented code held over from previous
  refactoring commits.

Fix broken unchecked cast of Number config opts

Apache Commons Config's properties file implementation seems to return
objects of type String even for small numbers that could fit in an
Integer.  In contrast, in-memory ACC configuration implementations
like those used in unit testing seem to store and return actual
numeric types (like Integer).  This commit changes
CommonsConfiguration.get(String, Class) to try to handle either case
gracefully when retrieving a value of type Number or a subtype of
Number.

Refactor metrics configuration handling

Previous to this commit, GraphDatabaseConfiguration used
metrics.enable-basic-metrics while Backend used
storage.enable-basic-metrics.  There's no good reason for these
options to be separate.  It's just confusing.

The config option wording is also clumsy.  In retrospect, it should
really have been metrics.enabled.  Titan's Metrics support and
metrics.* config namespace grew out of the storage backend, but now
Metrics covers other stuff in Titan besides storage.

To support existing configs, I made GraphDatabaseConfiguration and
Backend both consider metrics globally enabled when any one (or more)
of the following config options are set to true:

* storage.enable-basic-metrics
* metrics.enable-basic-metrics
* metrics.enabled

Storage backend metrics are merged when of the following are true
(they are each true by default):

* metrics.merge-basic-metrics
* storage.merge-basic-metrics

Update ConsistentKeyLockerTest for Metrics changes

ConsistentKeyLockerTest is, by design, extremely sensitive to
internals changes in ConsistentKeyLocker or AbstractLocker.  The test
started failing when I added calls to
tx.getConfiguration().getMetricsPrefix() in AbstractLocker.  In this
commit, I changed ConsistentKeyLocker to allow any number of calls to
tx.getConfiguration().  The configuration doesn't hold mutable lock
state, and this is the second time I've stumbled over spurious
tx.getConfiguration() failures in ConsistentKeyLockerTest, so I think
relaxing this constraint is appropriate.

Tweak getSlice and getKeys metrics names

* prevent getSlice from attempting to log metrics with an empty-string
  name prefix when metrics are disabled

* rename com.thinkaurelius.titan.getKeys.iterator.* to
  com.thinkaurelius.titan.stores.getKeys.iterator.* to conform with
  the naming pattern of every other storage metric

Rename ExpirationStoreCache metrics

When I originally added Metrics counters to this class, I mistakenly
set the counter names to just "ExpirationStoreCache".  Now the names
start with GraphDatabaseConfiguration.METRICS_SYSTEM_PREFIX_DEFAULT +
"." + "ExpirationStoreCache".  In other words, the metrics in here now
start with "com.thinkaurelius.titan.sys.ExpirationStoreCache".

Add Metrics counters on locking operations

Metrics counters added for calls to and exceptions in the write,
check, and delete lock methods of AbstractLocker.  ConsistentKeyLocker
extends AbstractLocker.  A transaction-specific metrics name prefix is
honored when set.

Reformat broken debug log message

Fixes #544

Wrap QueryExecutor implementations with Metrics

This times and counts (invocations and exceptions counted separately)
calls to the methods on implementations of the QueryExecutor
interface, when the calling transaction has metrics enabled.  Any
transaction-specific metrics prefix, if configured, is honored.  Time
spent in iterators returned by methods on the QueryExecutor interface
are *not* covered by these metrics.  This is part of #402.

Replacing AtomicLongs with Metrics Counters

Because Metric counters do not support the notion of set/reset/clear,
only increment and decrement, ExpirationStoreCache's metrics reset
methods are now at best approximate.  The reset methods may set their
respective counters back to zero, or they set them down to a value
slightly above zero.

titan.sh: kill Cassandra only after Rexster dies

`titan.sh stop` now waits up to 60 seconds by default (though this is
configurable through an environment variable) for Rexster to disappear
from the jps process table before attempting to kill Cassandra.  This
addresses issue 2 of 2 in #538.

Expunge uses of `uname -o` from shell scripts

The -o option is not POSIX standard and does not exist on OS X (and
possibly other platforms).  Replaced with calls to just `uname`,
without options, which under POSIX must behave the same as `uname -s`.

This change is untested.  It's intended to address #534, but needs to
be verified manually before closing the issue.

Increase HBase and Cassandra timeouts in testing

Changed CONNECTION_TIMEOUT_KEY from 10s to 60s for Cassandra and HBase
tests.  This was motivated by performance testing on EC2, where
truncating column families on Cassandra could take over ten seconds
after many iterations of the same test method (truncating CFs after
each run).  I'm not sure why this operation was slow, but since it's
just CF truncation in clearStorage() and so far does not appear to
affect querying, I'm just going to bump up the timeout.  The 60s value
made the timeouts disappear on an EC2 c3.xlarge.

Tweaking JRE6 pom stylesheet

Avoid overlapping template matches in jre6.xslt

When multiple template patterns in a stylesheet match, Saxon throws a
warning and continues parsing.  In this case the multiple match is
harmless, but the warning is scary so I'm making a minor change to
avoid the match overlap.

dependencyManagement versions.  I would probably have to use
pluginManagement here, but that just makes it less readable since the
plugin is only used one time.

There was no reason for these two messages to be logged at ERROR.
They belong at DEBUG or at most INFO.

titan-dist-server include those new tests.  Also added a BDB + ES test
in titan-dist-all.

Remove stale reference to jre7.xslt

I removed this stylesheet a few commits ago, but a reference to it
lived on in pom.xml.  Deleted.

Remove jre7 profiles from poms

JRE7-compatible behavior is now the pom default.  Keeping these
profiles no longer makes sense now that I've added a stylesheet to

Reducing iteration count in testTranactionalMemory

A single execution of this method takes approximately 35 minutes on an
EC2 m1.medium.  This is unnecessarily for performance testing purposes

I reduced the iteration count by an order of magnitude (100k to 10k)

Tweaks to performance test surefire config

Make HBase shutdown more carefully in tests

When running memory and performance tests through Maven, I found that
HBase would die after perf tests but fail to restart for mem tests.

This turned out to be ZK failing to bind its port.  The HBase test
harness killed the HBase process with SIGTERM, which seems to prevent
ZK from cleanly closing its listen socket, which then goes into
TIME_WAIT and prevents the next ZK process from binding the port.

To fix this, I made the test harness first try to stop HBase using the
clean shutdown script provided with the HBase distro, waiting up to 20
seconds for it to finish.  If it doesn't finish, the harness resorts
to SIGKILL (not TERM).

This approach seems to resolve the issue -- now perf and mem tests
both run successfully.

Fixing timestamp handling bug in CK locker

ExpectedValueCheckingStore and ConsistentKeyLocker still expected
their store.mutate(...) calls to use the current timestamp.  Since the
timestamp is now controlled by StoreTxConfig, the locking code wound
up writing all its mutations within a tx with the same timestamp.
This led to thousands of warnings when testing EVCS and CKL on top of
titan-cassandra.

This commit makes each mutate call use a fresh timestamp.

titan-cassandra also recently got a new performance-regression test in
the form of TitanEventualGraphTest#testCachePerformance().  This isn't
part of @Category({ PerformanceTests.class }).  It's intended to be
run as part of the regular test suite as a "sanity check" on the
performance of the cache subsystem.  But titan-cassandra executes its
tests in multiple threads, so while the test passed in isolation, it
would sometimes randomly fail when other threads won the scheduler
wars.  Now this test has its own @Category({ SerialTests.class }) and
it runs in its own single-threaded surefire execution.

This commit adds support for Infinispan's SingleFileStoreCache

configuration code involved is pretty trivial compared to the
transactional stuff.

implementation into Infinispan's GlobalConfiguration by default.  I
tested this a few days back on EC2 when doing replicated cluster

Initial commit of Infinispan transaction support

This introduces Infinispan transaction support backed by the JBoss
Transaction Manager, also known as Narayana and the core module of
which is known as Arjuna.  The implementation uses javax.transaction
where possible, which should theoretically ease a potential switch to
an alternative JTA/JTS transaction provider (say, Atomikos).

This commit also changes the Infinispan store configuration from
non-transactional to transactional for all tests.  I'll add the
nontransactional configuration back in as a separate test execution in
a future commit, so that each test for Infinispan is executed in both
a transactional and nontransactional configuration.

I also removed the Infinispan LockKeyColumnValueStoreTest, since its
semantics make no sense for a store that has builtin key-level locking
that doesn't implement acquireLock.  It may make sense to re-add it
with a nontransactional config.

This code is new, just barely tested, and should be assumed buggy.

ExpectedValueCheckingStore tx handling tweaks

Failing to commit/close/flush lock store transactions doesn't matter
for backends that actually use ExpectedValueCheckingStore, but it
leads to transaction leakage under pathological configurations of
other stores (like Infinispan configured to use
ExpectedValueCheckingStore instead of Infinispan's own native locking
mechanism)

Make titan.sh wait for Cassandra's Thrift server

and sleeping for a hardcoded interval, titan.sh now starts Cassandra
and then calls `nodetool statusthrift` and waits up to 60 seconds

to stderr and exits without attempting to start Rexster.

Adding StaticBuffer serializer for Infinispan

This should probably be part of the default Infinispan global
configuration if it works, but as of this commit it can be enabled in
infinispan.xml:

<infinispan>
  <global>
    <serialization>
      <advancedExternalizers>
        <advancedExternalizer externalizerClass="com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.infinispan.ext.StaticBufferAE"/>
      </advancedExternalizers>
    </serialization>
  </global>
</infinispan>

The serializer performs no compression.  It just reads/writes integer
lengths followed by bytes.  I've only tested it on some tiny graph
traversals on EC2 so far, and it worked fine there.

Import and unused variable cleanups in Infinispan

Extending ISPN configuration options

InfinispanCacheStoreManager gains two configuration options:

* conffile (GraphDatabaseConfiguration.STORAGE_CONF_FILE_KEY)
* cacheprefix (ICSM.INFINISPAN_CACHE_NAME_PREFIX_KEY)

The former defaults to null.  When it is non-null, it is interpreted
as a path to an Infinispan XML config file and that file is used to
instantiate the EmbeddedCacheManager instance.  When it is null, the
default Infinispan global configuration takes effect.

The latter defaults to titan.  ICSM now uses cachenames in the form
<prefix>:<dbname>.  For example, under the default configuration, the
cache names are:

* titan:titan_ids
* titan:edgestore
* titan:edgestore_lock_
* titan:vertexindex
* titan:vertexindex_lock_
* titan:edgeindex

The prefix is omitted from the value returned by
InfinispanCacheStore#getName() and intended to be hidden from the
graphdb layer above it.

Why add this feature?  Potential use cases for the configurable prefix
include:

* running multiple distinct ISPN-backed databases concurrently, each
  with its own prefix

* resolving potential cache name conflicts with other ISPN clients
  (i.e. playing nice in a cotenant ISPN deployment)

* switching between different cache configs/tunings without
  necessarily rewriting infinispan.xml every time

Shutdown graph properly in Infinispan graphdb test

Avoids the following spurious exception caused when merely clearing
the graph storage after a test completes without shutting the graph
down entirely:

Exception in thread "Thread-112" com.thinkaurelius.titan.core.TitanException: Could not acquire new ID block from storage
        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.graphdb.database.idassigner.StandardIDPool.renewBuffer(StandardIDPool.java:116)
        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.graphdb.database.idassigner.StandardIDPool.access$100(StandardIDPool.java:14)
        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.graphdb.database.idassigner.StandardIDPool$IDBlockThread.run(StandardIDPool.java:171)
Caused by: com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.PermanentStorageException: It seems there is a race-condition in the block application. If you have multiple Titan instances running on one physical machine, ensure that they have unique machine idAuthorities
        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.diskstorage.idmanagement.ConsistentKeyIDManager.getIDBlock(ConsistentKeyIDManager.java:122)
        at com.thinkaurelius.titan.graphdb.database.idassigner.StandardIDPool.renewBuffer(StandardIDPool.java:110)
        ... 2 more

Made it mandatory for all storage backends to provide key consistency and removed TransactionalIDAuthority. Now, all stores use the KeyConsistentIDAuthority which allows operating transactional stores with disabled transactions without data corruption.
This refactoring effectively de-couples transactionality from the id allocation mechanism which makes it safer and the code easier.

Note, that this introduces an incompatibility with prior releases for the following backends:
BerkeleyDB, Persistit, and Hazelcast
because their id allocation mechanism has changed.

Hence, this branch should only be merged with the next MAJOR release branch.

Added hashCode override to AbstractEquals

AbstractEquals#hashCode() now just calls super.hashCode().  This just

Rewrite ByteBufferUtil#hashcode(...) methods

The implementations of ByteBufferUtil#hashcode(...) for StaticBuffer
and ByteBuffer argument types seemed increasingly likely to go to zero
as the input size grew longer.  I found this accidentally through
Infinispan testing, where the prior implementation produced the
hashcode 0 for all StaticBuffer instances generated by the test
InfinispanCacheTitanGraphTest#testLargeJointIndexRetrieval (most of
which were nonzero overall but had many leading zero bytes).

I rewrote these methods according to the standard hashcode template in
Effective Java 2e by Josh Bloch (Item 9, page 47).

The change to hashcode(StaticBuffer) reduced the runtime of this IS
test method from about 6:30 to 0:15 on my box (minutes:seconds).  The
ByteBuffer version is untested.
(cherry picked from commit e8c90db30e811cbc5af6b6bdebaab7b40e50e2dc)

Cleanup titan-cassandra/pom.xml

This commit removes unreferenced properties and reduces the overall
size of the pom by moving the BOP/RP Cassandra test configurations out
of profiles and into the <build> tag of the pom.  Both the BP and RP
tests are enabled by default.  To skip one, set
-Dtest.skip.ordered=true or -Dtest.skip.unordered=true (respectively).
I would rather these properties be named test.ordered and
test.unordered and their boolean sense be negated, but I don't see an
easy way to do it with Maven right now.

Activate mem/perf test profiles using properties

Profile activation with -P... has proven brittle and limited because
of the way it interacts with <activeByDefault> (disables all marked
profiles in the same pom but not parent or child poms).  I'm changing
the memory-test and profile-test profile activation criteria.  Now
they activate when -Dtest.mem=true or -Dtest.perf=true are present on
the command line (respectively).  Using -Pperformance-test or
-Pmemory-test is not recommended.

Implements a property prefetching configuration option that will instruct transaction to load all properties on a vertex when a property is first looked up on the vertex. This leads to much better latencies on multiple vertex lookups against high latency storage backends and is hence enabled by default for distributed storage backends. Added performance test cases to validate its behavior and test performance. Closes #145

Fix two HBase store name shortening bugs

* Prior to commit, the short version of lock store names were strings
  like "v_lock_" whereas the desired name is a single character like
  "w".  This was caused by Backend generating lock store names by
  calling store.getName() on the non-lock counterpart and appending
  the lock suffix.  Now HBase remembers the store name originally used
  to open the database and returns it from getName().

* Fixed bug where HBaseStoreManager would open a new store instance
  every time openDatabase(s) was called for some fixed string s when
  CF name shortening was enabled.  I think this was harmless from a
  correctenss point of view, but it needlessly wasted memory.

Move HBase dependencyManagement to top level pom

This commit fixes dependency convergence for titan-all.  Before this
commit, building titan-all with a non-default Hadoop target failed
because it depended upon titan-hbase but ignored the
dependencyManagement stanza in titan-hbase/pom.xml necessary for
resolving version conflicts.  I pushed the dependencyManagement
section up to the top level pom.

I also deliberately omitted zookeeper's dependencyManagement stanza,
since I don't think it's actually needed.  Might be mistaken.

Disable HBase GC info

GC information is apparently only logged to the logs/hbase.out file
when the HBase daemon runs.  Invoking the HBase shell, on the other
hand, results in a bunch of GC information cluttering stdout and
making it hard to interact with the shell.

Rewrite HBase test harness

This commit updates the default HBase version in titan-hbase from
0.94.7 to 0.94.12.  The new test harness and pom supports targeting
Hadoop versions besides the default.  I tested retargeting with Hadoop
versions 2.0.0-alpha and 2.2.0.  The default Hadoop target version
remains unchanged at 1.0.4.

Updating the HBase version from 0.94.7 to .12 should be safe:

http://hbase.apache.org/upgrading.html#hbase.binary.compatibility

Convert HBase short CF name map to bimap

Also, when configured to shorten CF names, make the HBase store
manager sanity-check CF names passed into openDatabase.  shortnames of
the longname<->shortname bimap are disallowed.  Only longnames or
strings that aren't present on either side of the bimap are allowed.

Statically check HBase short CF name integrity

New static initializer guarantees that the map of long CF names to
short equivalents is injective, that is, that no two distinct long
names map to the same short name.

Include lock stores in HBase short CF names map

Now the _lock_ counterparts to the vertex index, edge index, edge
store, and id store are also shortened.  The one-char short names of
the lock stores alphabetically follow the one-char short names of
their non-lock counterparts.  The id store maps to "i" and the id lock
store maps to "j", etc.

Added option to shorten HBase CF names

Per advice in http://hbase.apache.org/book/rowkey.design.html#keysize.cf

This option's configuration property key is storage.short-cf-names.
It's honored only by the HBase store manager.  It's disabled by
default.

Major untested Metrics refactoring

Made Metrics configuration transaction-centric.  Each graph
transaction can be configured to disable metrics, enable metrics, or
enable metrics with a custom metric name prefix.  The last option is
intended to let users segregate Metrics measurements generated by
Titan in whatever way they like -- for instance, by setting the
metrics prefix to the name of an application or the name of an account
originating the tx.  User provided metric prefix strings override the
Titan default and will appear in whatever Metrics reporter targets the
user configures, such as Ganglia or Graphite.

This commit is a probably-buggy refactoring baseline.  It reflects the
broad strokes structural changes that I wanted to do in Metrics
configuration, but I've probably messed up the details somewhere.

Tweaks to satisfy the release plugin

The release:prepare goal solicits a new version for titan-dist-parent,
but because it only appears through pom inheritance and not through a
module relationship, it appears to do nothing with that new version,
leading to an error in release:prepare's invocation of the verify
phase.  This hack attempts to trick release:prepare into adding
titan-dist-parent as a submodule of the toplevel pom.

Copy prerelease Furnace generators into titan-test

titan-test uses com.tinkerpop.furnace.generators, but Furnace has yet
to be released.  Only SNAPSHOT versions are available.  We can't
release Titan with a SNAPSHOT dependency on Furnace.  As a hack, I
copied the source for the generators subpackage into titan-test's
source tree and changed the package name to
com.tinkerpop.furnace.alpha.generators.  The generators subpackage
happens to be self-contained and depends on no other Furnace files.

I commented the Furnace SNAPSHOT dependency in titan-test/pom.xml.

This should all get reverted when Furnace releases and we can depend
on it in releases.

A new Expect-based release archive test

I'm trying this out.  When running "mvn verify -Paurelius-release" in
titan-dist-berkeleyje, an integration test extracts the distribution
zipfile and runs an Expect script that spawns gremlin.sh and runs a
few trivial commands (adds a vertex and commits it).  If any of the
expect subcommands timeout or don't see what they want, then the
script exits with nonzero status and the integration test fails, in
turn failing the verify lifecycle stage for the module.
