Refactor poms to allow JDK cross-compiling

The current Titan source can't build on JDK 6 (tested Oracle 6u45)
because TitanVertexQuery inherits two unrelated return types for
the method limit(int); this is supported in 7 but not 6.

Here's the exact wording of the compiler error on Oracle 6u45:

[ERROR] /home/dalaro/tinkerelius/titan/titan-core/src/main/java/com/thinkaurelius/titan/core/TitanVertexQuery.java:[16,7] types com.tinkerpop.blueprints.VertexQuery and com.thinkaurelius.titan.core.BaseVertexQuery are incompatible; both define limit(int), but with unrelated return types

Related bug: http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=6908259

However, we can still compile Titan using JDK 7 with -source 1.6
-target 1.6 and -Xbootclasspath:/path/to/jdk/rt.jar.  This does not
throw the error above.

This commit records the first complete set of project poms that can
build for both jars and assemblies -target 1.6 and -target 1.7.  It's
still rough and could use some cleanup.  In particular, the "jre6" and
"standard" profiles that I introduced in this commit are unnecessary
whenever the set of dependencies in each case is identical, differing
only in the dependency classifiers on titan artifacts.  I didn't
realize that at the start, so this commit includes a combination of
approaches for managing dependencies under the two compilation
targets.  Also, the names "jre6" and "standard" for compilation
targeting profiles are bad.

Merge branch 'indexing4'

Column slice hack for CacheStoreAdapter#getKeys

This commit adds code to check whether keys returned by the unordered
getKeys(SliceQuery, StoreTransaction) method actually contain columns
matching the slice.  It's a hack and not particularly efficient.

Hacking HazelcastKCVS to check column slices

Why did getSlice explicitly use a signed bytes comparator when testing
columns against the lower and upper slice bounds?  It's clear that
this was deliberate, but I can't see the reasoning behind it.  It
makes a current getSlice test fail.

I changed that to unsigned and also implemented a naive column bounds
check in getKeys.  This getKeys hack could be smarter about the
caching columns it reads during slice checking for potential later
reuse by getEntries, but I'm sticking with the simple-and-dumb version
initially.

Heavily-conflicted inmemory->master merge attempt

This had both conflicted diff hunks, as noted in the
automatically-generated list below, and diff hunks that applied
perfectly but caused compile errors.  Although all tests except those
in Hazelcast pass (more on that later), this was a substantial merge
and I could easily have made a mistake somewhere.

Some points of contention:

* inmemory removed the KVS getKeys(tx)

* master replaced beginTransaction(ConsistencyLevel) with
  beginTransaction(StoreTxConfig)

* inmemory modified KCVSTest to hold only one transaction open at any
  given time, whereas master did not have this refactoring but did
  have a few new test method additions; also, inmemory renamed the
  testStore public static final variable used by name in many
  subclasses

* master refactored KeyIterator to implement Iterator<StaticBuffer>,
  while inmemory rewrote several KeyIterator implementations to
  account for the first bullet in this list (I think)

* inmemory removed ensureClosed() checks inside KeyIterator hasNext()
  and next() implementations for reasons I don't understand

* minor StoreFeatures refactoring differences between master and
  inmemory, but I think those are trivial

There may be other stuff I missed.

Hazelcast is disabled because one of the new getKeys-exercising
methods in KCVSTest seemed to expose a bug in the implementation -- it
looks like it might not honor column slice values for certain
invocations of getKeys.  I'm commenting the module in the top-level
pom until I investigate the failure.

Make BytesToken format hack safe on other tokens

Check that objects of general type Token<?> pass an instanceof
BytesToken check before trying to apply a hack for
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-5566

I think it was impossible for the hack to have fired prior to this
commit.  It was guarded by a regex on Token strings that looked for
"Token(bytes[.+])".  Murmur3- and RandomPartitioner return LongToken
and BigIntegerToken, respectively, whose toString() methods both
return strings containing only decimal digits and a minus sign.

Still, I think the check is useful in case somebody has a third-party
partitioner that uses tokens returning arbitrary strings.

Reverting maven-surefire from 2.16 to 2.15

2.16 included a regression that makes it impossible to run a single
test method.  It's still possible to run all methods in a single class,
just not a specific method.

 http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/SUREFIRE-1028

According to the 2.16 changelog in JIRA, the only substantial changes
vs 2.15 were new parallel test execution options, none of which we
actually use right now.  I do use single-method test execution though.

Monster getKeys refactoring and testing commit

The getKeys(KeyRangeQuery keyQuery, StoreTransaction txh) method in
the Astyanax and Thrift stores seemed to be untested and broken.  This
is the getKeys method that takes both a column range and key range.
Its only supported when the backend stores keys in byte order (BOP, in
this case).

The Thrift adapter had these bugs:

* For Cassandra versions 1.2.4 and earlier,
  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-5566 makes the
  client send broken slice tokens when BOP is in effect.  The server
  can't parse the tokens, logging an error and triggering an exception
  client-side.  Slicing by key is not affected -- only by tokens.
  This has a pretty simple workaround, and it goes away in 1.2.5 and
  up.  I actually already verified that it's fixed on 1.2.10, but then
  I had to revert to 1.2.2 when I discovered that Astyanax has a hard
  incompatibility (trying to call a nonexistent constructor) with
  1.2.10.

* The ordered getKeys checked for `partitioner instanceof
  OrderPreservingPartitioner` and threw an exception if false.  But
  this is always false with BOP.  BOP doesn't inherit from OPP and
  never has AFAIK (= moderate certainty back to about 0.7).  Changed
  OPP in the instanceof check to AbstractByteOrderedPartitioner.  I
  have an extremely strong sense of dj vu about this bug, but I
  don't know where in the revision history I might have previously
  fixed it, if at all.

* The last key was returned by the ordered getKeys method.  Judging
  from KeyRangeQuery and the tests for this method, I think the last
  key is supposed to be considered exclusive.

The Astyanax adapter just had the last bug in the list above.  I fixed
all of the above (I think).

I fixed the first bullet point about junk BOP tokens in a
forward-compatible way.  When we go to 1.2.5 and beyond, the
workaround should quietly turn itself off at runtime.  Then we can
remove it as soon as we're ready to drop compatibility with prior
versions.  I also added forward-compatibility to
CassandraThriftStorageManager's token handling; it wasn't buggy on our
current Cassandra version, but it would have failed when we eventually
upgrade to 1.2.5 and beyond.

I refactored Cassandra tests and the way Maven runs them.  By default,
all Cassandra tests now run twice with Maven: once under BOP and once
under RP.

Test classes or methods can be marked as eligible for only BOP or RP
by annotating them with

 @Category({ UnorderedKeyStoreTests.class })

or

 @Category({ OrderedKeyStoreTests.class })

There is also an annotation which explicitly declares the subject
compatible with either type of store, but it is redundant, because
that is the default behavior under the current Maven config:

 @Category({ KeyOrderAgnosticTests.class })

All of the annotation argument classes are in the package
com.thinkaurelius.titan.testcategory in titan-test.

Eclipse's native JUnit runner appears to have no way to honor the new
JUnit @Category annotation, so it will blithely try to run all tests
regardless of their categories using the default config, which I've
set to BOP.  When Eclipse runs an BOP-only test with a RP config, it
fails.  I haven't found a clean way to workaround that yet.  We could
make all the tests interrogate StoreFeatures to see what's possible,
but that will add some boilerplate.  It would be worth the boilerplate
to get the tests to "just work" in Eclipse though.

Finally, both ExpectedValueCheckingStore and
BufferedKeyColumnValueStore had bugs in both of their getKeys methods:
the one that takes a SliceQuery and the other that takes a
KeyRangeQuery.  They weren't unwrapping their transactions when
interacting with the wrapped store.

I also finished removing Rexster classes, test classes, and Maven
dependencies.

Renaming Cassandra compression config keys

Removed the "cassandra.db." prefix from these Cassandra configuration
keys:

* compression.enabled
* compression.chunk_length_kb
* compression.sstable_compression

Also: the middle option in the list was formerly chunk_size_kb.  I
changed it to chunk_length_kb because that's the string Cassandra uses
and I don't see a reason why the need to be subtly different.

I think the "cassandra" prefix is redundant because graph configs have
"storage.backend", which must be set to a one of the strings
identifying a Cassandra backend for any of these keys to be read by
Titan in the first place.  "db" is debatable.

Refactoring CF compression in embedded Cassandra

* Added support for disabling compression entirely in the embedded
  cassandra adapter per the config key introduced in #379

* Removed code that instantiates a compressor class from the embedded
  store manager, instead passing a string to Cassandra's
  CompressionParameters constructor.  The constructor handles
  reflective instantiation on our behalf.  This is an improvement
  because CompressionParameters contains logic to prepend
  "org.apache.cassandra.io.compress." to compressor strings that
  contain no dots, allowing shorthands like "SnappyCompressor".
  That's also our current default compressor string.

* Expanded debug log statements around compressor configuration in the
  embedded adapter

Refactor Cassandra's sstable_compression config

* Renamed SSTABLE_COMPRESSION in AbstractCassandraStoreManager to
  COMPRESSION_KEY to match the existing pattern of public static final
  String config keys in that class

* Added psfS DEFAULT_COMPRESSION set to "SnappyCompressor" instead of
  passing the literal directly to the config parsing code

* Changed user-visible "sstable-compression" configuration key to
  "cassandra.db.compression.sstable_compression" to match the pattern
  of the other two Cassandra-compression-related config keys.  I think
  having "Cassandra" is definitely redundant, and "db" is probably
  redundant, so I may change this again.

Fix broken TitanGraphConcurrentTest method

The test testStandardIndexVertexPropertyReads left open transactions
besides the class member named tx.  This commit foregoes opening those
transactions in the first place, instead sharing the class member tx
across several concurrent methods.

This commit also makes the test method wait for the runnables it
submits to an executorservice to complete by get()'ing their futures.
This was previously racy: tearDown() would wait five seconds for the
executor's tasks to complete and then it would throw an exception.
Now the method waits until all the tasks it started are complete
before returning and allowing control transfer to tearDown().

Added TransactionBuilder interface which gives the user the ability to configure transactions prior to opening them and thereby controlling performance and consistency checking aspects of the transaction on a per transaction basis. Use TitanGraph.buildTransaction() for that.
One aspect TransactionBuilder lets you control is whether a TitanTransaction should verify the existence of all vertices internally. Since this is expensive, its disabled by default but can selectively be enabled via TransactionBuilder in the face of data degradation  on eventually consistent storage backends.

Add client-side ES version check (fixes #338)

At compile-time, Titan's ES version is written to titan-es.properties.
The properties file gets included in the titan-es jar.
ElasticSearchConstants loads the properties file at runtime using
getResourceAsStream(...), just like TitanConstants.
ElasticSearchConstants then converts the version into a public static
final field on ES's Version class and loads that reflectively.
Finally, ElasticSearchIndex compares this expected version against
Version.CURRENT at runtime and logs a warning if they don't match.

Note that a version mismatch does *not* throw an exception.  It just
logs a warning.

This is all hideous and byantine and awful.  I wish there was an
easier way to check the ES version using only strings.  It's so easy
to get the cluster's version using the REST HTTP API, but I don't see
an equivalent way to do it with only the Java API, and I don't want to
add a whole second client to the ES index implementation just to read
a 6-byte version string.

Revert "Moving titan-dist-* submodules into their parent"

This reverts commit 09f33171c3601018926a094f6a5cd0ad91a37e8a.

The previous commit tried multiple profiles with different dependency
sets in the same pom.xml, with the intent that each profile's
execution would get evaluated using only its dependency set.  This is
futile when multiple profiles are active at the same time.  All of the
profiles' dependencies are merged into a single set shared across all
profile executions.  I don't see a way to have different dependency
trees in the same execution of a single pom.xml, so I'm reverting back
to lots of distro submodules.

Extracted Gremlin imports into utility class

Console.java now relies on a new class, ConsoleSetup.java, to supply a
list of imports/import-statics to execute when bootstrapping a Gremlin
shell for Titan.  The utility class also contains a main method that
writes the imports to stdout or a file.  This is useful for generating
a Rexster <init-script> file for use with Titan that imports all the
same symbols as an interactive gremlin.sh session.  It also avoids
copy-pasting, so that any time we update the import list effective in
gremlin.sh, we will also automatically update the Rexster environment.

Comment changes, cleanup in JUnitBenchmarkProvider

Moved performance test tuning into JUBProvider

Logic to estimate JUB test method benchmark rounds required to run for
a total of 5 seconds, save those multipliers to a file, read them, and
modify the JUnitBenchmarks configuration accordingly is now
concentrated solely in JUnitBenchmarkProvider, instead of being split
across JUnitBenchmarkProvider and GroovyTestSupport.  The
implementation uses java.lang.reflect.Proxy to generate a dynamic
proxy annotation instance and intercept JUB's call to the
benchmarkRounds() method for each test.  This is sort of byzantine,
but it's the best I can do, given the severe limits on inheritance in
both JUnit and JUnitBenchmarks via the final keyword and restrictive
method visibility modifiers.

Customizing imports in zip/tarball Rexster cfg

This shows that we can mirror the customized imports in Titan's
Console.java file in Rexster without modifying Rexster's source or
resorting to an extension.  However, this commit introduces
copy-pasted duplication between Console.java and rexster.xml.  I think
I see a better way to do this now.  The logic in Console.java that
executes groovy import statements should be extracted into a static
method or a method on some new throwaway object.  It will return
groovy code.  A new main method should be introduced to call this
helper method and write the code to a file.  Rexster can then be
configured to execute it via the <init-scripts> configuration option
in the <script-engine> stanza for Gremlin.  It might even be possible
to build this into the titan-dist maven lifecycle, so that it's fully
automated.

Added JUnitBenchmarks method runtime normalization

I added a new implementation of JUB's IResultsConsumer interface to
JUnitBenchmarkProvider.  This consumer gets execution data from JUB
and writes the method classname, method name, and 1000 / runtime_in_ms
to a file, in that order, separated by spaces.  JUnitBenchmarkProvider
automatically enables this consumer when the environment variable
JUB_WRITE_SCALARS is set and contains a valid file path.  It appends
to the file rather than overwriting it.

JUnitBenchmarkProvider can also parse this file via a static helper
method, returning a map of classname.methodname to millisecond
runtime.

This commit also contains some minor refactoring in GroovySerialTest
and GroovyTestSupport.

Removing IDAuthority's peekNextID method

In the consistentkey backend, this peek method could skip valid
blocks, limiting its usefulness.  It deosn't appear to be used
anywhere outside a single test method, so I deleted the method from
both its interface and implementations.

In the consistentkey implementation of IDAuthority, the process of
allocating a block happens in approximately two steps.  1. Write the
backend to claim an ID block.  2. If the write took longer than a
certain configurable time limit, try to delete it, otherwise return
the block as successfully allocated.

The problem: "peek" just looks at written claims.  If peek happens
after a write completed but before the responsible machine deletes it,
then peek will consider it allocated and skip it.  A subsequent call
for the next block may then return a start less than what peek
reported.

If we come up with a genuine need to peek at ID blocks, then we'll
need to modify the consistentkey implementation to avoid this behavior
(unless we can live with it, somehow).

Initial Sonar support in pom.xml files

This changeset generates a single JaCoCo coverage file containing the
aggregated coverage data for all Maven modules containing tests.  It
also adds a Sonar plugin configuration that uploads the coverage data
to a Sonar server.  The approach is inelegant, but it seemed to be the
least worst compromise between various tooling limitations.  In
particular, Sonar operates on a per-module basis, and it appears to
discard coverage data for source files outside the module it's
currently considering.  This is a problem for our project, since most
of our tests exercise code across Maven module boundaries.

Enabling maven-enforcer's DependencyConvergence

This enforcer rule walks the dependency tree throws an error if it
finds multiple versions of any one dependency.  It prints the paths it
walked from the project root to each of the dependency declarations.

This suspends maven's automatic version conflict resolution.  The user
has to resolve all conflicts by explicitly excluding unwanted versions
(including those pulled in transitively --
dependencies-of-dependencies).

Allowing maven to automatically resolve dependency versions resulted
in more than one version within each of the lucene-*, asm-*, and
jersey-* sets of jars, and that has caused problems with two of those
sets so far.

I attempted to resolve the backlog of conflicts somewhat sensibly,
though these initial version selections will likely need fine tuning.
The project builds and the tests pass, but this is still sort of an
experiment.

CacheVertex: fix broken double-checked locking

This bug repeatedly caused the following NPE in one of our
nondeterministic stress tests.  I ran into the exception by accident
while generating sample data with JUnitBenchmarks.

I think this bug could be fixed by marking one of
relationCache/queryCache volatile, always writing the volatile one
strictly after the nonvolatile one, and always using the volatile one
in DCL if-statements.  However, this code looked like a maintenance
hazard when I wrote it out -- a change as innocent as reordering
assignments to these two state variables could cause it to break.  So
I went with a holder pattern instead, even though it's probably
slower.

Tweaks for timeout-sensitive failure on Travis

Travis builds 227.1 and .3 failed due to the same exception in the
same test method, parallelNoncontendedLockStressTest.  The log
suggests that locks are expiring before the LockStressor threads in
this test can check their locks, resulting in an underrun on a success
counter and the assertion shown in the logs.

I made two changes:

* Changed expire exception type from PermanentLockingException to
  TemporaryLockingException and made the test count the sum of
  successful locked operations and operations that failed due to
  TemporaryLockingExceptions (but not Permanent or any other type)

* Increased the test's lock expire time from 1s to 5s

I also added a log statement that might help check my analysis if the
build fails again on Travis.  This commit passed the test suite
locally, but so did the commit that just failed on Travis.

Merge branch 'lock-refactoring'

The conflicts were mainly at the intersection of the refactored
consistentkey locking code and parallel testing in Cassandra.
LocalLockMediators were not in keyspace-specific namespaces to keep
parallel Cassandra tests from interfering and causing false local lock
contention.  I think I resolved it in this commit, but if I did make
an error merging, it's probably got something to do with
LocalLockMediator configuration in the new ConsistentKey- and/or
AstyanaxRecipeLocker.

The complete Titan test suite did pass on my box the three consecutive
times that I ran it before committing.

Made script to update gh-pages at release time

When the titan-site maven module is packaged with -Ptitan-release, it
will write a script target/site-scripts/gh-pages-update.sh.  This
script takes as its sole argument a release.properties file generated
by mvn release:prepare.  The script checks out a new copy of the repo
on branch gh-pages, then locally stages new javadoc, wikidoc, and a
new root index.html appropriate for the release version (the "release
version" is read from release.properties).  The script adds all its
changes to the git index but does not commit or push, leaving the
chance for the user to inspect and potentially modify its output.

Major repo layout and pom refactoring

This commit collects experimental release-engineering commits from the
fork github.com/dalaro2/titan, plus some additional commits from my
local repo.  I used a fork under the bogouser dalaro2 while
experimenting with release automation to keep my credentials separate
and reduce the likelihood of unintentionally pushing a "release" of
titan.  However, the dalaro2/titan commit history is noisy and
confusing because of all the fake releases and revert commits that I
made while testing.  The net changes are fairly small when expressed
as a patch between the common ancestor commit in titan03
(771fb4e10a2494c6569a210a16f8d3187aa4ae87) and the fork head, so I'm

Reverse commons-config automatic list parsing

Rexster calls TitanGraphConfiguration#convertConfiguration with what
Apache Commons Config calls a "hierarchical" configuration.  This
subset of Commons Config automatically turns comma-separated string
values into lists.  TitanGraphConfiguration needs to join these lists
back together as Strings for e.g. passing a list of seeds to a
Cassandra backend.  RexsterTitanServer does not use hierarchical
configurations and is not exposed to this automatic list parsing.

Track thread exceptions in testMultiIDAcquisition

The method testMultiIDAcquisition in LockKeyColumnValueStoreTest
manually instantiated and started threads.  Assertion failures inside
those threads would appear on stderr, but they wouldn't be visible to
the JUnit runner and hence wouldn't directly fail the enclosing test.
Failures were detected indirectly by scrutinizing some state variables
after all the threads finished running.

This commit replaces manual thread instantiation with a standard
library ExecutorService.  The ES returns a Future for every Runnable
given to it.  The Future's get() method in turn throws an
ExecutionException containing any exception (such as an assertion
failure) generated by the runnable.  The test method rethrows these
exceptions when they occur, effectively making them visible to JUnit.

Allow timeouts when stress-testing ID authorities

This commit changes LockKeyColumnValueStoreTest's
testMultiIDAcquisition().  Now the tolerates ID authorities that
intermittently throw StorageException (e.g. due to a backend timeout),
so long as the correct number of correctly-sized id blocks are
allocated in sequential order.  The test now permits an ID allocator
to "skip" id blocks (which can happen on timeout in the current
ConsistentKey implementation) so long as the rest of the constraints
are respected.

Stop caching lock column values

If writing a lock claim to a storage backend took longer than
LOCK_WAIT_MS to complete, then later attempts to verify that lock
claim would generate a guaranteed "timestamp mismtach"
PermanentLockingException.  This should now be fixed.

This was due to an interaction between
ConsistentKeyLockTransaction#writeBlindLockClaim(...) and
LockClaim#getLockCol(long ts, byte[] rid).  The former calls the
latter.  The latter calculated a return value only on its first
invocation, cached it, and then returned it on that and all subsequent
invocations.  It did this even if the ts argument, on which the return
value depended, varied between invocations.  In cases where a lock
claim write took longer than LOCK_WAIT_MS to succeed, this caching
behavior made retries write a stale timestamp and later caused a
"timestamp mismatch" exception.  This commit makes getLockCol(...)
calculate its return value on every invocation.

This should alleviate one potential cause of timeout mismatch
exceptions as discussed in #302.

Relax lock timestamp mismatch check

Writing a lock claim to storage may appear to fail on the client,
generating a StorageException, even though it actually succeeded.  For
example, a Cassandra cluster could complete a write but fail to
acknowledge it before triggering a TimeoutException.  These claims
linger in storage and pointlessly block lock aquisition by other
processes until aging past the lock expiration time.

This commit changes the lock verification step to accept a sequence of
claims sharing the same rid and differing only in their timestamps, so
long as the final timestamp matches that expected by the verifier.
This should alleviate one potential cause of timeout mismatch
exceptions as discussed in #302.

Setup MemoryMeter agent for Cassadra tests

The Cassandra tests currently spam this warning:

WARN org.apache.cassandra.db.Memtable - MemoryMeter uninitialized
(jamm not specified as java agent); assuming liveRatio of 10.0.
Usually this means cassandra-env.sh disabled jamm because you are
using a buggy JRE; upgrade to the Sun JRE instead

This downloads @jbellis's jamm project before running tests and points
the -javaagent JVM argument at the downloaded JAR file.  This
optimistically assumes JVM support for JAMM without actually checking
for it.  This means JAMM could break terribly when run using a really
old OpenJDK version or any JVM that doesn't work properly with JAMM.

Change default Astyanax backoff configuration

Issue #291 shows Astyanax's connection timeout logic generating a
negative sleep time.  The log timestamps in the issue suggest that the
Astyanax timeout configuration is the default.

By default, Titan uses Astyanax's BoundedExponentialBackoff to
generate timeouts.  Though Thread.sleep() eventually gets a long
value, BoundedExponentialBackoff and parent class ExponentialBackoff
use int arithmetic internally.  This leads to integer overflow and
wraparound to negative values when baseWaitTimeMS * (1 <<
(attemptcount + 1)) crosses Integer.MAX_VALUE.  Our default
configuration ran afoul of this on its final timeout attempt before
exhausting its 30 retries.

This commit changes the defaults to:
* base wait time: 100 ms
* maximum attempts/retries/exponent: 8
* maximum allowed wait time: 25000 ms

The maximum integer calculated in ExponentialBackoff will be 100 * (1
<< (7+1)) = 25600, well below overflow (and that will in turn be
capped at 25000).

Change WeakHashMap to ConcurrentHashMap

The WeakHashMap in TitanBlueprintsGraph can be accessed concurrently
by multiple threads.  This access pattern is tested in
TransactionalGraphTestSuite#testCompetingThreads().  The javadoc for
WeakHashMap says the collection is unsynchronized.  When running the
test on my box, these unsynchronized concurrent accesses seem to the
type of failure seen in #284.

I changed the WeakHashMap to a ConcurrentHashMap.
Collections.synchronizedMap(new WeakHashMap()) would also work, but I
suspect that we want concurrency more than we want the ability to
automatically forget and GC uncommitted/unrollbacked transactions.

Prevent lock failure from zombie writes

ConsistentKeyLockTransaction#verifyAllLockClaims neglected to verify
that the lock claim timestamp read from storage matched the timestamp
on the corresponding LockClaim object in memory.  This could lead to
lock exclusion failures when clients perceived failure on write
operations that actually succeeded.  Such zombie writes can happen,
for example, in a Cassandra cluster with hinted handoff enabled where
fewer than QUORUM replicas are available during the lock claim write
and at least QUORUM fully-repaired replicas are available during the
subsequent lock claim read.

Removed Rexster-Titan client, updated test cases to use RexsterClient

Revert "Remove RexsterTitanClient and related tests #257."

This reverts commit 8fdf105643bc811aeffdfbca5a1b455f4d0ac288.

Fixing broken Map calls in Thrift mutateMany()

Calls to get() on this map received StaticBuffer, while calls to put()
received ByteBuffer.  These types never return true for equals(), so
get() always returned null.  This was a bug introduced during the
ByteBuffer to StaticBuffer & friends conversion.

For additional discussion about the bug's failure mode, see the log
for 6aa352dc29c3fb0fe0ca3c80be328de32f74b42f.

Add test to catch new type of mutateMany() error

During the migration from ByteBuffer to StaticBuffer and friends, I
missed a Map in CassandraThriftStoreManager#mutateMany() that for
which get() calls used StaticBuffer keys but put() calls used
ByteBuffer keys.  These two types never equals() one another, so get()
always returned null.  The resulting bug made mutateMany() write each
key provided in its argument in at most one column family.  If a key
appeared under multiple column families in mutateMany()'s argument,
then only one CF actually received writes on the key, and all
additions/deteletions under the key in question were ignored for the
remaining CFs.

This bug caused a failure in a tangentially related test that touched
the buggy code plus a lot of other code.  This test just exercises the
buggy code.

A fix for the mutateMany() bug comes in the next commit.

Fix Cassandra Thrift end boundary handling

This commit fixes essentially the same problem my previous Astyanax
commit fixed.  An equals() call was comparing an object of type
StaticBuffer to ByteBuffer and unconditionally failing, causing
getSlice() calls to erroneously return the slice end instead of
excluding it.

Fix Astyanax slice end boundary handling

The Astyanax becakend had an equals() call comparing StaticBuffer and
ByteBuffer.  Because the concrete types differed, this call
unconditionally returned false.  Fixed to compare objects of the same
concrete type.

This failing equals() check caused the end boundary in Astyanax
getSlice() calls to be erroneously included in the results when it
should have been excluded.

Comment cleanup

I meant to delete this piece of comment verbiage in my last commit.

Type fix in Astyanax getSlice()

The Astyanax class RowQuery<K, C> has two colliding/ambiguous method
signatures for withColumnRange() when K=C=ByteBuffer.  I'm using the
raw type to avoid this problem, but it's an unclean solution and
prevents the compiler from typechecking the first two arguments to
withColumnRange.  These used to be ByteBuffers but were changed to
StaticBuffer in a recent commit, causing Astyanax to die.  This patch
converts the StaticBuffers back to ByteBuffers.  I'd still rather find
a way to let the compiler typecheck the method call in question
without running aground on ambguous signatures.

Fixed bug that causes Titan to not load the right edges when a limit is applied to the query. This bug had two consequences:
1) For queries with limits and constraints, it would only load a partial result set (or an empty one).
2) Subsequent queries on the same vertex would also return only partial result sets (even if those queries did not have a limit on them).
Fixed bug that arises when two vertex id sets with different implementations are merged during a query.

This was formerly just com.thinkaurelius.  Issue #65 is moving towards
a multi-artifact Titan build.  Community convention points towards
creating a subnamespace in com.thinkaurelius.titan for these
collections of related artifacts; projects on Maven Central under the
org.apache and org.sonatype tend to do the same thing.
Javadoc edits
Comment edits
Adding Whirr config to run HBase 0.92.1

Fixed two expiration timing bugs in locking code

One of these timing bugs was brain damage left over from my last
commit: there were attempted conversions in LockingTransactionHandle
from milli- to nanoseconds using a factor of 1000 instead of 100000.

The other timing bug was older than my last commit.
LockingTransactionHandle read nanosecond timestamps from the storage
backend, but then proceeded to try to figure out whether those
timestamps had expired by comparing them to milliseconds without
conversion.

I've added test cases in LockKeyColumnValueStoreTest that should look
for these cases.

LockingTransactionHandle is pretty fragile at this point.  It could
probably benefit from some refactoring to reduce method size and
per-method control structure nesting depth.  It might be wise to make
it uniformly handle only nanosecond timestamps, too.

Added configuration option whether new vertices are maintained in a transaction to save memory in batch loading scenarios.
Refactored TransactionConfig to use "has" instead of "do".

LocalLockManager tweaks

This commit is a bundle of changes copied over in patch form from
another workstation.  I should probably be using git-bundle.

Usability tweaks for Embedded Cassandra

CassandraDaemonWrapper now sets the cassandra-foreground system
property to prevent Cassandra from closing stdout and stderr during
initialization.  The wrapper also starts Cassandra using a daemon
thread so that it can't block shutdown of the JVM.

Thanks @BinaryRage for pointing out these issues.

Tweaked cassandra.yaml for 1.1.x

Added the global row and key cache configuration options new to 1.1.x.
The key-cache is sized according to Cassandra's default value of
min(5% of Heap (in MB), 100MB).  The row-cache is 512 MB.

Made unlock code continue despite Exceptions

The loop to release all locks held by a transaction could be
prematurely exited by an exception, such as TimedOutException, thrown
during the backend interaction for any one of the locks.

The current behavior encloses every unlock attempt in its own
try-catch block.  This means that individual unlocks could still
timeout, but unlockAll() will not give up on the rest of its
outstanding locks after the first exception it encounters.

This commit also adds some assertions and logging statements to
unlockAll().

Added autostart to embedded-Cassandra backend

When a newly-added CassandraEmbeddedStorageManager configuration
property is set, the storage manager constructor will start a
Cassandra thread in the background using the cassandra.yaml file
pointed to by the config property.  This is internally synchronized to
avoid starting multiple Cassandra threads in a single JVM, so
subsequent constructor invocations can't start additional Cassandra
threads even when this config property is set.

sitting between Thrift and StorageProxy in Cassandra mainline.

in mainline have been removed in this implementation.

Changed method name from startThreadedTransaction to startTransaction

ID allocation race fix for OCKVS stores

Formerly, the ID allocator would write a column to its backing store,
wait a little while, and then read the entire row containing the
column it just wrote.  The ID allocator then decided whether it
succeeded by checking whether the lexicographically last column on the
row was the one it just wrote.

This created a potential to enter the the following (racy) livelock:

A starts loop, reads partition row, gets latest counter C
A writes column claiming C+1
B reads partition row, gets latest counter C+1
B writes column claiming C+2
A starts verification, reads partition row, gets latest counter C+2 from B
A determines that it failed, since B's C+2 comes after its C+1
A starts loop, reads partition row, gets latest counter C+2 again
A writes column claiming C+3
B starts verification, reads partition row, gets latest counter C+3 from A
B determines that it failed, since A's C+3 comes after its C+2
B starts loop, reads partition row, gets latest counter C+3 again
B writes column claiming C+4
... and so on to failure by exceeding maximum retries

The ID allocator now avoids this by reading just a slice of the
partition row, instead of the whole partition row, during
verification; the slice contains only those columns that start with
the targeted counter value.  This prevents an ID allocator from seeing
claims for counter values higher than the one it is currently
attemting to grab.

Like the rest of the current ID allocation implementation, this is OK
for fixed-size and fixed-offset blocks (I think) but would be
incorrect for variable block sizes.  We don't implement variable block
sizes yet in the ID allocator, so this is not a material concern right
now.

This change is just a few lines, but the code is delicate.  All the
InternalCassandra* and InternalAstyanax* tests pass on my machine with
this change, but it is otherwise untested.

New Astyanax config options

These Astyanax options have been added (but not thoroughly tested):

* keyspace replication factor
* read consistency level
* write consistency level
* per-operation retry policy
* cluster node discovery mode
* connection pooler type
* maximum open connections per host

Hack to fix #17

When Titan's Cassandra keyspace was removed by external (non-Titan)
means, stale pooled Thrift connections and OKVCS objects would linger.
The Cassandra-Thrift backend subsequently failed to detect the absent
keyspace and recreate it.

On Titan systems with multiple local-lock-mediator-prefix settings,
this patch could potentially cause rendundant but harmless recreation
of CassandraThriftOKCVS objects.  This configuration only appears in
testing.  It still wouldn't hurt to refine this behavior out.

  up that Eclipse exposes.  I'm not sure.

  the upshot that this method is unnecessary.

HBase: fix mutateMany timestamps

Replaced hard-coded timestamp value of 0L (and the TODO comments
alongside them) with timestamps generated from
System.currentTimeMillis().  Specifically, the timestamp for all
deletions is equal to the value returned by System.currentTimeMillis()
early in mutateMany, and the timestamp for all puts is that plus one.
Just before returning, the method checks wthere
System.currentTimeMillis() returns a value higher than the put
timestamp; if not, it does Thread.sleep(1L) calls until this is so.

Added Cassandra daemon embedding for testing

The tests formerly known as CassandraThriftKeyColumnValueTest,
CassandraLockKeyColumnValueStoreTest, and CassandraGrapTest are now
prefixed with "External".  This signifies that they start Cassandra in
a process external to the JVM process for testing purposes.  Also
added are the same classes with "Internal" in place of "External";
these use a newly-added thin wrapper around the
org.apache.cassandra.thrift.CassandraDaemon class to start a Cassandra
instance inside the JVM executing the tests.

pom.xml also excludes the newer Avro artifact required by HBase in
favor of the older one required by Cassandra (this conflict caused
fatal exceptions when trying to run an embedded Cassandra instance as
described in the previous paragraph).  This might have broken HBase
support.  We will almost certainly have to revisit this temporary
exclusion later.

Refactored locking to reduce ConcurrentHashMap accesses

HBase and Cassandra OrderedKeyColumnValueStore implementations now are
supplied with their locking store and local lock mediator at
construction, and they pass these two things to LockingTransactions as
needed.  This replaces what was formerly a ConcurrentHashMap get in
each case.

Any refactoring on the distributed locking code makes me uneasy.  The
full test suite passes on my machine, but these changes affect a
fragile subsystem.

On an unrelated note, I added an exclusion for the sonatype gossip
artifact.  This is an slf4j binding which is a dependency of gremlin
(possibly with some degree of transitivity between gremlin and
gossip).  It conflicted with the existing log4j binding for slf4j.
I'm not sure that log4j is really better for Titan than gossip; I just
kept log4j because it's been in the Titan codebase for so long.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:thinkaurelius/titan

HBase locking and ID allocation refactoring

Initial HBase implementation of locking and ID alloction, along
with refactoring to the Cassandra implementation of each to support
a shared implementation where reasonable.  CassandraTransaction
has finally been abstracted out to a key-column-value-store-agnostic
diskstorage.locking.LockingTransaction.  CassandraTransaction and
HBaseTransaction extend LockingTransaction but add and override
nothing; these subtypes only exist to generate class cast exceptions
in case a user does something nonsensical, like open an HBase
transaction and then try to acquire locks on that transaction using
an unrelated Cassandra store.

Cassandra refactoring and ID alloc bugfix

This commit removes the last of CassandraTransaction's dependencies on
the CassandraThriftStorageManager type.  CassandraTransaction now has
a reference of type StorageManager where it formerly needed a
CassandraThriftStorageManager.  Locking column families are now lazily
created in the backing Cassandra cluster (whereas they were formerly
created eagerly during openDatabase()).

This commit also fixes a bug in the ID allocation code for Cassandra.
Formerly, this code wasn't waiting after writing an ID block claim for
the time period mandated by the protocol draft.  This could have
caused contending claimants on an ID block to fail to detect their
contention.  Now the code waits after writing an ID block when
necessary.  This bug wasn't exposed under our current test cases and
is fundamentally tricky to test because it's racy and distributed.

This commit also adds commented logic for a close() implementation on
KCVStores that actually does something.  Cassandra doesn't use or
really need a functioning close() method right now, so its commented,
but I'm putting it in this commit for potential future reference.

Fix regression in LockKCVStoreTest

Logic to configure Rid and LocalLockMediator appropriately for faux-remote
transactions was lost during test case refactoring.  I added an abstract
method configureTransactions() to LockKCVSTest for the purpose of
backend-specific transactions tweaks.  This is not an elegant solution and
may be refactored out of existence later, but it gets the test case back to
succeeding for now.  The only subclass of LockKCVStoreTest that actually
works right now is for Cassandra, but this fix should also apply to HBase
when we test it.

Major refactoring of Configuration management and diskstorage interfaces:

- Storage backend specific configuration is removed. StorageManager constructor is assumed to take Configuration as argument and loaded dynamically using reflection

HBase storage adaptor updates

* Replaced single private-final HTable instance in each HBase KCVStore
  with an HTablePool.  Each method pulls an HTable off of this pool
  and onto its stack, then returns it in a finally block.

* Reimplemented the mutate method to use HTable#batch instead of
  separate HTable#delete and HTable#put calls.  I would rather use
  RowMutations, but that only appears in 0.94 which is not yet on the
  public Maven repositories

* Deleted obsolete, commented method bodies from before the

Implemented complex edge query

Cassandra mutate cleanups and timestamp changes

The timestamps used by the Cassandra-Thrift KCV store now approximate
the number of nanoseconds since the UNIX Epoch.  I estimate the
imprecision in this approximation as up to about one millisecond of
slowness wrt true time.  The error bound can be tuned downward with
increasingly fancy static initializer code.

The final bit in any timestamp is 0 for delete mutations and 1 for
insert mutations.  This limits effective time precision in timestamps
to 2 ns increments.

The mutate and mutateMany methods in the Cassandra-Thrift KCV store
have been reimplemented to make just one batch_mutate call to the
Cassandra backend.  The obsolete insert, delete, insertMany, and
deleteMany methods are gone.  The only public methods besides the ctor
in this class are now @Overrides of some current interface method.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:thinkaurelius/titan

Fixed timestamp-related race in Cassandra-Thrift backend

The Cassandra backend prior to this commit used
System.currentTimeMillis() as the timestamp for mutations.  When Titan
issued multiple writes to a certain key and column within a single
millisecond, the tie would be broken by lexical comparison on value.
This is unacceptable for Titan.

As a temporary solution, mutations issued to any given Cassandra
Thrift backend are now effectively limited to a rate of one per
millisecond.  The mutation stream issued by Titan is also guaranteed a
strictly increasing series of timestamps via an AtomicLong stored
inside the CassandraThriftOKCVS.

The current 1 mutation/ms limitation could be made granular by (a)
tracking timestamp series on a per-key, per-column, or per-key-column
basis or (b) using a smaller time unit than milliseconds in the
Cassandra timestamp field; 2^64 ms is about 584 million years; we
could steal some of those bits to provide micro or nanosecond
precision, but then we would need to either abandon wall-clock
accuracy beyond millisecond precision or use something like JNA to
call native timekeeping functions that offer such precision; even
then, NTPv4 is only so accurate.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master'

Conflicts:
	src/test/java/com/thinkaurelius/titan/graphdb/test/AbstractGraphDBTest.java
Bugfixing.

Cassandra dependency cleanup and testing tweak

I deleted pom.xml deps leftover from when Cassandra wasn't distributed
to Maven Central.  I also increased the cassandra-all dep version from
1.0.7 to 1.1.0 (the current release).

The Cassandra test config also seemed to be allowing Cassandra too
small a heap to survive through the full series of test methods in
CassandraThriftKeyColumnValueTest.  The daemon would sometimes die
partway through this test class, at which point the Thrift client
binding would typically emit a timeout or premature socket EOF error.
I changed the test to stop and start Cassandra between each test
method, as opposed to using one daemon for the entire class.  I expect
to take another look at this when checking our Cassandra testing
configs for 1.1.x compatibility.

Unstable HBase backend and Cassandra cleanups

Both the HBase and Cassandra backends exhibit failures under test.

There's now a rudimentary HBase OrderedKeyColumnValue store with no
locking, no transactions, and no performance testing.  It passes the
OrderedKeyColumnValueStore test, but both it and the Cassandra Thrift
backend fail the GraphDBTest.  You must start a HBase server before
running the HBase tests -- they just assume there's a server up that
they can talk to.  Interestingly, while the Cassandra and HBase
backends fail several methods in GraphDBTest, InMemory also fails one
(for what are likely reasons unique to it).

I added HBase and hadoop-core dependencies to pom.xml.

I also updated the testing cassandra.yaml file and Cassandra
CTConnectionFactory class to be compatible with Cassandra 1.1.0.
